verses.text: I composed the first treatise, O Theophilus, concerning all that Jesus began both to do and to teach,
until the day he was taken up, after he had given instructions through the Holy Spirit to the apostles whom he had chosen.
To these men he also presented himself alive after his suffering by many convincing proofs, appearing to them over a period of forty days and speaking about the matters of the Kingdom of God.
While eating salt with them, he commanded them not to depart from Jerusalem, but to wait for the promise of the Father, "which," he said, "you heard from me;
for while John baptized with water, you will be baptized in the Holy Spirit not many days from now."
So when they had come together, they began asking him, "Lord, is it at this time that you are restoring the sovereignty to Israel?"
He said to them, "It is not for you to know the spans of time or the appointed moments which the Father has set within his own authority.
But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you, and you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem, in all Judea and Samaria, and to the furthest reaches of the earth."
After he had said these things, while they were watching, he was lifted up, and a cloud took him from their sight.
As they were gazing intently into the sky while he was going, look! Two men in white clothing stood beside them
and said, "Men of Galilee, why do you stand looking into the sky? This same Jesus, who was taken up from you into heaven, will come in the same way you saw him going into heaven."
Then they returned to Jerusalem from the mount called 'of Olives,' which is near Jerusalem, a Sabbath’s journey away.

When they entered the city, they went up to the upstairs room where they were staying: Peter and John and James and Andrew, Philip and Thomas, Bartholomew and Matthew, James the son of Alphaeus and Simon the Zealot and Judas the son of James.
All these were persisting with one mind in prayer, along with the women and Mary the mother of Jesus, and with his brothers.
In those days, Peter stood up in the midst of the brothers (the crowd of persons gathered together was about one hundred and twenty) and said,
"Brothers, it was necessary for the Scripture to be fulfilled which the Holy Spirit spoke beforehand through the mouth of David concerning Judas, who became a guide for those who arrested Jesus.
For he was numbered among us and was allotted a share in this ministry."
(Now this man acquired a field with the reward of his unrighteousness, and falling face-forward, he burst open in the middle and all his intestines spilled out.
This became known to everyone living in Jerusalem, so that the field was called in their own dialect 'Akeldama,' that is, 'Field of Blood.')
"For it is written in the Book of Psalms: *Let his homestead become desolate and let there be no one living in it*, and, *Let another take his position of oversight.*
Therefore, it is necessary that of the men who accompanied us during all the time the Lord Jesus went in and out among us—
beginning from the baptism of John until the day he was taken up from us—one of these must become a witness of his resurrection along with us."
So they put forward two: Joseph called Barsabbas, who was also called Justus, and Matthias.
And they prayed and said, "You, Lord, who know the hearts of everyone, show which one of these two you have chosen
to take the place in this ministry and apostleship from which Judas turned aside to go to his own place."
Then they cast lots for them, and the lot fell on Matthias, and he was counted together with the eleven apostles.

chapters.notes:
**"First treatise" (v. 1)**: The Greek *logos* here refers to a formal written account or book. Using "treatise" honors the literary structure of Luke-Acts as a two-volume work.

**"Convincing proofs" (v. 3)**: The term *tekmēriois* refers to evidence that is demonstrable and certain, distinguishing it from mere testimony or hearsay.

**"While eating salt with them" (v. 4)**: The Greek *synalizomenos* is a difficult term. While some translate it simply as "gathering with them," its etymological roots and the Aramaic cultural context suggest "sharing salt"—a metaphor for table fellowship and the sealing of a covenant. Given Jesus’s post-resurrection appearances often involved eating (Luke 24:41-43), this rendering captures the intimate, communal nature of the setting.

**"Sovereignty" (v. 6)**: The Greek *basileia* is often "kingdom," but in the context of the disciples’ question, they are asking about the restoration of national self-rule and political power to Israel. "Sovereignty" captures this political dimension.

**"Spans of time or appointed moments" (v. 7)**: This preserves the distinction between *chronous* (quantitative time, durations) and *kairous* (qualitative time, decisive or divinely appointed moments).

**"Furthest reaches of the earth" (v. 8)**: The phrase *eschatou tēs gēs* likely refers not just to distance, but to the ends of the known world (the Roman ecumene), signaling the universal scope of the mission.

**"A Sabbath's journey" (v. 12)**: This is a specific Jewish measurement (approx. 2,000 cubits or 0.6 miles) based on Rabbinic interpretations of the Law. It signals to the reader the proximity of the mount to the city while grounding the narrative in Jewish legal reality.

**"Persons" (v. 15)**: The Greek *onomatōn* literally means "names," but in this context, it is a Semitic idiom (often found in the Septuagint) referring to people in a census or list.

**"Allotted a share" (v. 17)**: The Greek *elachen ton klēron* uses the language of "lots." This creates a literary "bookend" with verse 26, where the replacement is chosen by lot.

**"Position of oversight" (v. 20)**: The Greek *episkopēn* refers to an office or a charge of responsibility. It is the term from which "bishop" is derived, but here it refers to the specific functional role Judas vacated.

**"Know the hearts of everyone" (v. 24)**: The Greek *kardiognōsta* is a compound word ("heart-knower"). It is an attribute of God common in Jewish prayer, emphasizing divine election over human preference.

verses.text: When the day of Pentecost had fully arrived, they were all gathered together in one place.
Suddenly, a sound like the rush of a violent blast of wind came from heaven and filled the entire house where they were sitting.
Divided tongues, appearing like fire, became visible to them and settled on each one of them.
They were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in different languages, as the Spirit gave them the ability to speak with inspired colonial weight.
Now there were devout Jews from every nation under heaven living in Jerusalem.
When this sound occurred, the crowd gathered and was thrown into confusion, because each person heard them speaking in their own native dialect.
They were completely astonished and amazed, saying, "Look, are not all these who are speaking Galileans?
How is it then that each of us hears them in our own native dialect in which we were born?
Parthians, Medes, and Elamites; residents of Mesopotamia, Judea and Cappadocia, Pontus and Asia,
Phrygia and Pamphylia, Egypt and the regions of Libya near Cyrene; visitors from Rome,
both Jews and converts to Judaism; Cretans and Arabs—we hear them speaking in our own languages about the magnificent works of God!"
They were all utterly perplexed and stayed in a state of uncertainty, saying to one another, "What does this mean?"
But others were mocking them, saying, "They are full of new, sweet wine!"

But Peter, standing with the eleven, raised his voice and addressed them with inspired solemnity: "Men of Judea and all who live in Jerusalem, let this be known to you, and pay close attention to my words.
These men are not drunk, as you suppose, for it is only the third hour of the day.
Rather, this is what was spoken through the prophet Joel:

‘And it shall be in the last days,’ says God, ‘that I will pour out from my Spirit upon all flesh; your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your young men shall see visions, and your old men shall dream dreams.
Even upon my male servants and my female servants in those days I will pour out from my Spirit, and they shall prophesy.
I will produce wonders in the heaven above and signs on the earth below: blood, and fire, and a cloud of smoke.
The sun shall be turned into darkness and the moon into blood, before the arrival of the great and glorious day of the Lord.
And it shall be that everyone who calls upon the name of the Lord will be saved.’

“Men of Israel, listen to these words: Jesus the Nazarene was a man publicly authenticated to you by God through miracles, wonders, and signs that God performed through him in your midst, just as you yourselves know.
This man, delivered up by the predetermined counsel and foreknowledge of God, you executed by nailing him to a cross through the hands of lawless men.
But God raised him up, having released the birth-pangs of death, because it was impossible for him to be held in its power.
For David says concerning him: ‘I saw the Lord before me continually, for he is at my right hand so that I will not be shaken.
Therefore my heart was glad and my tongue rejoiced; moreover, my flesh will live in hope.
For you will not abandon my soul to Hades, nor will you allow your Holy One to experience decay.
You have made known to me the paths of life; you will fill me with gladness in your presence.’
“Brothers, I can speak with confidence to you about the patriarch David, that he both died and was buried, and his tomb is among us to this day.
Therefore, since he was a prophet and knew that God had sworn to him with an oath to seat one of his descendants upon his throne,
he spoke with foresight concerning the resurrection of the Messiah: that he was neither abandoned to Hades, nor did his flesh experience decay.
This Jesus, God raised up, and of this we are all witnesses.
Therefore, having been exalted to the right hand of God, and having received from the Father the promise of the Holy Spirit, he has poured out this which you both see and hear.
For David did not ascend into the heavens, but he himself says: ‘The Lord said to my Lord: “Sit at my right hand,
until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet.”’
“Therefore, let the entire house of Israel know with certainty that God has made him both Lord and Messiah—this Jesus whom you crucified!”
Now when they heard this, they were pierced to the heart and said to Peter and the rest of the apostles, “Brothers, what should we do?”

Peter said to them, “Repent—change your hearts and lives—and let each of you be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.
For the promise is for you, and for your children, and for all those who are far away—as many as the Lord our God may call to himself.”
With many other words he continued to testify and to exhort them, saying, “Be saved from this crooked and perverse generation!”
So those who welcomed his message were baptized, and about three thousand souls were added that day.
They were devoting themselves to the teaching of the apostles and to the common life, to the breaking of bread and to the prayers.
A sense of awe came over every soul, and many wonders and signs were being performed through the apostles.
All who believed were together and held all things in common;
they would sell their possessions and property and distribute the proceeds to everyone, according to what anyone needed.
Every day, they continued to meet together in the temple courts with a single purpose, and breaking bread from house to house, they shared their food with gladness and sincerity of heart,
praising God and having the goodwill of all the people. And every day the Lord added to their number those who were being saved.

chapters.notes:
**"Pentecost" (v. 1)**: The Greek *pentēkostēs* refers to the "fiftieth" day after Passover. To the original audience, this was the Feast of Weeks (*Shavuot*), a harvest festival that also came to be associated with the giving of the Torah at Sinai.

**"Inspired solemnity / Inspired weight" (v. 4, 14, 40)**: The Greek *apophhtheggesthai* is more than simple speaking (*lalein*). It refers to the bold, public utterance of a prophet or a philosopher under divine influence. The translation "inspired" captures this specialized, elevated tone.

**"Dialect" (v. 6, 8)**: The text uses *dialektō* rather than just *glōssa* (language). This suggests the listeners heard not just the general language, but their specific local vernaculars.

**"New, sweet wine" (v. 13)**: *Gleukous* refers to the juice that drips from the grapes before they are pressed—a high-sugar "must" that ferments into a very potent, sweet wine.

**"From my Spirit" (v. 17, 18)**: The Greek uses the partitive *apo* ("from" or "of"). This nuances the pouring out as an bestowal from the infinite source of God’s Spirit, rather than the Spirit being a finite liquid.

**"Lawless men" (v. 23)**: *Anomōn* refers specifically to those "without the Law" (*Torah*), meaning the Gentiles (specifically the Romans) who carried out the execution.

**"Birth-pangs of death" (v. 24)**: This preserves the striking Greek metaphor *ōdinas tou thanatou*. While many translations use "pains" or "agony," the Greek term specifically refers to labor pains. This suggests that death was not an end, but a labor that could not hold the life of the Messiah.

**"Hades" (v. 27, 31)**: The Greek *hadēs* is used here (as in the Septuagint) to translate the Hebrew *Sheol*, the place of the dead. Using "Hades" avoids the modern geographic or moral connotations of "Hell."

**"Decay" (v. 27, 31)**: *Diaphthoran* refers to the physical decomposition and corruption of a corpse.

**"Repent" (v. 38)**: *Metanoēsate* implies a total "change of mind" or radical reorientation of one's life and direction, rather than mere regret.

**"Common life" (v. 42)**: *Koinōnia* is often translated "fellowship," but in the context of the following verses (sharing property and meals), it implies a deep, tangible communal participation.

**"Sincerity of heart" (v. 46)**: *Aphelotēti* literally means "smoothness" (as in a field with the stones removed). It suggests a heart without hidden bumps or agendas—simplicity and singleness of purpose.

verses.text: Now Peter and John were going up to the temple for the three o’clock hour of prayer.

A certain man who had been lame from his mother’s womb was being carried there; every day they would place him at the temple gate known as "The Beautiful Gate" so he could beg for charity from those entering the temple complex.
When he saw Peter and John about to go into the temple, he began asking them for a gift of mercy.
Peter, along with John, looked at him with an intense, fixed gaze and said, "Look at us!"
The man fixed his attention on them, expecting to receive something from them.
But Peter said, "I have no silver or gold, but what I do have, I give to you: In the name of Jesus Christ the Nazarene, walk!"
Then, taking him by the right hand, Peter raised him up. Immediately the man’s feet and ankles were made firm.
Leaping up, he stood and began to walk; then he entered the temple with them, walking and leaping and praising God.
All the people saw him walking and praising God.
They recognized him as the one who used to sit for charity at the Beautiful Gate of the temple, and they were filled with a sense of awe and sheer astonishment at what had happened to him.
While the man was still clinging to Peter and John, all the people—utterly overwhelmed—ran together to them at the portico called Solomon’s.
When Peter saw this, he addressed the people: "Men of Israel, why are you amazed at this? Or why do you stare so intensely at us, as if by our own power or personal piety we had made him walk?
The God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—the God of our fathers—has glorified his Servant Jesus, whom you handed over and rejected in the presence of Pilate, even though he had decided to release him.
You rejected the Holy and Righteous One and demanded that a murderer be granted to you as a favor.
You killed the Source and Sovereign of Life, whom God raised from the dead—of which we are witnesses.

And by faith in his name, his name itself has made this man strong, whom you see and know. Indeed, the faith that comes through Jesus has given this man this complete wholeness in the presence of you all.
"And now, brothers, I know that you acted in ignorance, just as your rulers did.
But in this way, God fulfilled what he had announced beforehand through the mouth of all the prophets—that his Messiah would suffer.
Repent, therefore, and turn back to God, so that your sins may be wiped away,
so that seasons of refreshing relief may come from the presence of the Lord, and that he may send the Messiah appointed for you, Jesus.
He must remain in heaven until the time for the restoration of all things, which God spoke about long ago through the mouth of his holy prophets.
"Moses indeed said, 'The Lord your God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your own brothers. You must listen to him in everything he says to you.
And every soul that does not listen to that prophet will be completely cut off from the people.'
And all the prophets from Samuel and those who followed, as many as have spoken, also announced these days.
You are the heirs of the prophets and of the covenant that God established with your fathers when he said to Abraham, 'And through your offspring, all the families of the earth will be blessed.'
When God raised up his Servant, he sent him to you first, to bless you by turning each of you away from your wicked ways."

chapters.notes:
**"Three o'clock hour" (v. 1)**: The Greek text specifies the "ninth hour." In the first-century Jewish reckoning of time, the day began at sunrise (roughly 6:00 AM), making the ninth hour 3:00 PM—the time of the evening sacrifice and prayer.

**"Charity" / "Gift of mercy" (v. 2, 3)**: The Greek *eleēmosynē* (the root of the English word "almoner") refers to acts of mercy or the money given to the poor. Using "charity" or "gift of mercy" captures the religious obligation and the spirit of the act better than the more archaic "alms."

**"Intense, fixed gaze" (v. 4)**: The verb *atenizō* is a favorite of Luke’s, denoting a piercing, unwavering look. It implies more than just "looking"; it suggests a moment of divine or spiritual concentration.

**"The Nazarene" (v. 6)**: The Greek *tou Nazōraiou* is a specific title. While it relates to his hometown of Nazareth, it functioned as a distinct identifier (and sometimes a slur) that Peter here reclaims as a title of power.

**"Servant" (v. 13, 26)**: The Greek *pais* can mean "child" or "servant." In this context, it is a deliberate allusion to the "Servant of the Lord" (*Ebed Yahweh*) in the Septuagint version of Isaiah (e.g., Isaiah 42, 52-53).

**"Source and Sovereign of Life" (v. 15)**: The term *archēgos* is difficult to translate with one word. It refers to a pioneer, a founder, a chief leader, or the originator of something. He is the one who "leads the way" into life. "Source and Sovereign" attempts to capture both the creative and the ruling nuances.

**"Complete wholeness" (v. 16)**: The Greek *holoklēria* refers to a state of being "whole in all its parts." It emphasizes that the healing wasn't just functional but a total restoration of the man’s physical integrity.

**"Messiah" (v. 18, 20)**: The Greek *christos* is the translation of the Hebrew *mashiach*. In a speech addressed to "Men of Israel" (v. 12) regarding the "God of Abraham" (v. 13), the title's Jewish meaning is primary. "Messiah" captures the national and theological expectations of the audience better than the transliterated "Christ."

**"Wiped away" (v. 19)**: The verb *exaleiphō* means to erase, as one would wipe ink off a papyrus or a wax tablet. The imagery is the total removal of a written record of debt or sin.

**"Refreshing relief" (v. 20)**: The Greek *anapsyxis* literally means a "recovery of breath" or a "cooling." It suggests a relief from heat or a respite from burdens.

**"Restoration of all things" (v. 21)**: *Apokatastasis* is a technical term for the return of a situation to its original, intended state. In the context of Jewish prophecy, it refers to the renewal of the world and the fulfillment of God's promises to Israel.

**"Offspring" (v. 25)**: The Greek *sperma* (seed) is singular, which Peter (and other NT authors like Paul) understood as pointing specifically to the Messiah as the representative descendant of Abraham.

verses.text: While they were still speaking to the people, the priests, the captain of the temple guard, and the Sadducees came upon them.
They were deeply disturbed because the apostles were teaching the people and proclaiming that in the person of Jesus there is a resurrection from among the dead.
They seized them and put them in custody until the next morning, for it was already evening.
But many of those who had heard the message believed, and the number of the men grew to about five thousand.
The next day, the rulers, the elders, and the scholars of the Law gathered in Jerusalem,
including Annas the High Priest, Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and all those of the high-priestly lineage.
They made the apostles stand in their midst and began to interrogate them: “By what kind of power or by what name did people like you do this?”
Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them: “Rulers of the people and elders,
if we are being cross-examined today regarding a good deed done to a frail man—specifically, by what means he has been made whole—

let it be known to all of you and to all the people of Israel that by the name of Jesus Christ the Nazarene, whom you crucified but whom God raised from the dead—by him this man stands before you healthy.
This Jesus is ‘the stone rejected by you builders, which has become the cornerstone.’
There is no salvation in anyone else, for there is no other name under heaven given among humanity by which it is necessary for us to be made whole.”

When they observed the outspoken confidence of Peter and John and realized that they were men untrained in letters and mere commoners, they were amazed; they also began to recognize them as having been with Jesus.
But since they could see the man who had been healed standing right there with them, they had nothing to say in response.
So they ordered them to step outside the Sanhedrin and began to confer with one another,
saying, “What should we do with these men? For that a noteworthy sign has occurred through them is evident to everyone living in Jerusalem, and we cannot deny it.
But to keep this from spreading any further among the people, let us threaten them to speak no longer to anyone on the basis of this name.”
After calling them back in, they commanded them absolutely not to utter a sound or teach on the basis of the name of Jesus.
But Peter and John answered them, “Whether it is right in the sight of God to listen to you rather than to God, you must judge;
for we cannot stop speaking about what we have seen and heard.”
After threatening them further, they released them, finding no way to punish them because of the people, for everyone was glorifying God over what had happened.
For the man on whom this sign of healing had occurred was more than forty years old.
When they were released, they went to their own people and reported everything the chief priests and the elders had said to them.
When the believers heard it, they raised their voices to God with one mind and said: “Sovereign Master, you are the one who made the heaven, the earth, the sea, and everything in them.
You said by the Holy Spirit through the mouth of our father David, your servant: ‘Why did the nations rage, and the peoples plot in vain?
The kings of the earth took their stand, and the rulers gathered together as one against the Lord and against his Anointed.’
For in truth, they gathered together in this city against your holy servant Jesus, whom you anointed—both Herod and Pontius Pilate, along with the Gentiles and the peoples of Israel—
to do whatever your hand and your purpose had predestined to happen.
And now, Lord, look upon their threats and grant your bondservants the ability to speak your word with all outspoken confidence,
while you stretch out your hand for healing, and signs and wonders take place through the name of your holy servant Jesus.”
When they had prayed, the place where they were gathered was shaken, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak the word of God with outspoken confidence.
Now the entire group of those who believed were of one heart and soul, and not even one person claimed that any of his possessions was his own, but they held everything in common.
With great power the apostles continued to give their testimony to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and great grace was upon them all.
There was not a single needy person among them, for as many as were owners of lands or houses would sell them, bring the proceeds of the sales,
and lay them at the feet of the apostles. It was then distributed to each according to their need.
Joseph, whom the apostles called Barnabas (which means “Son of Encouragement”), a Levite and a Cypriot by birth,
sold a field that belonged to him, brought the money, and laid it at the feet of the apostles.

chapters.notes:
**"Deeply disturbed" (v. 2)**: The Greek *diaponoumenoi* suggests a mixture of being pained, annoyed, and intensely worked up. It captures the visceral frustration of the Sadducees, who specifically rejected the doctrine of the resurrection.

**"Made whole / Salvation" (v. 9, 12)**: The Greek verb *sōzō* and noun *sōtēria* carry a dual sense of physical healing/rescue and spiritual salvation. By using "made whole" in verse 9 (referring to the lame man) and verse 12 (referring to the human condition), the translation preserves the wordplay and the theological argument Peter is making: the physical healing is a sign of the greater restoration available only through Jesus.

**"Untrained in letters and mere commoners" (v. 13)**: *Agrammatoi* means they lacked formal rabbinic education; *idiōtai* refers to those who are "private" or "lay" people—not professionals or specialists. "Commoners" captures the social stigma intended by the Sanhedrin.

**"Outspoken confidence" (v. 13, 29, 31)**: *Parrēsia* is a key term in Acts. It refers to the democratic ideal of "free speech" or "boldness," specifically the courage to speak the truth plainly in the face of intimidating power. 

**"Sovereign Master" (v. 24)**: *Despota* (from which we get "despot") refers to a master with absolute authority. In this context of political persecution, the believers appeal to the one whose power overrules the "rulers of the earth."

**"Servant" (v. 25, 27, 30)**: The Greek *pais* can mean "child" or "servant." In these verses, it alludes to the "Servant of the Lord" from the Septuagint’s version of Isaiah (the *Ebed Adonai*), a messianic figure who suffers and is vindicated.

**"Son of Encouragement" (v. 36)**: *Paraklēsis* is difficult to translate with one word, as it encompasses comfort, exhortation, and encouragement. "Encouragement" is the most common fit for Barnabas’s character throughout Acts.

verses.text: But a certain man named Ananias, together with his wife Sapphira, sold a piece of property.
With his wife’s full knowledge, he secretly misappropriated some of the proceeds for himself; he brought only a portion of the money and laid it at the feet of the apostles.
But Peter said, “Ananias, why has Satan filled your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit and to secretly misappropriate some of the proceeds from the land?

While it remained unsold, did it not remain your own? And after it was sold, was the money not under your own authority? Why is it that you conceived this deed in your heart? You have not lied to mere men, but to God.”
As Ananias heard these words, he fell down and breathed his last. And a great fear came upon all who heard of it.
The younger men stood up, wrapped him in burial cloths, carried him out, and buried him.
Now an interval of about three hours passed, and his wife came in, unaware of what had happened.
Peter addressed her: “Tell me, did you sell the land for this amount?” She said, “Yes, for that amount.”

Then Peter said to her, “Why is it that you agreed together to put the Spirit of the Lord to the test? Look! The feet of those who buried your husband are at the door, and they will carry you out as well.”
Instantly, she fell at his feet and breathed her last. When the young men entered, they found her dead; they carried her out and buried her beside her husband.
And a great fear came upon the whole assembly and upon all who heard these things.
Now many signs and wonders were happening among the people through the hands of the apostles. They were all together with one mind in Solomon’s Portico.
None of the rest dared to join themselves to them, yet the people held them in high regard.
Furthermore, believers were being added to the Lord in increasing numbers—multitudes of both men and women—
so that they even carried the sick out into the main streets and laid them on cots and sleeping mats, so that as Peter passed by, at least his shadow might fall on some of them.
The multitude from the towns surrounding Jerusalem also gathered, bringing the sick and those tormented by unclean spirits, and every one of them was healed.
But the high priest and all his associates—that is, the sect of the Sadducees—rose up, filled with jealous indignation.
They arrested the apostles and put them in the public jail.
But during the night, an angel of the Lord opened the doors of the prison, led them out, and said,
“Go, stand in the temple courts and continue speaking to the people all the words of this Life.”

Having heard this, they entered the temple courts at daybreak and began to teach. Now when the high priest and his associates arrived, they summoned the Sanhedrin—the entire Senate of the sons of Israel—and sent word to the prison for the apostles to be brought.
But when the officers arrived, they did not find them in the prison; so they returned and reported,
“We found the prison locked with all security and the guards standing at the doors, but when we opened them, we found no one inside.”
When the captain of the temple guard and the chief priests heard these words, they were utterly at a loss concerning them, wondering what this would come to.
Then someone arrived and reported to them, “Look! The men you put in prison are standing in the temple courts and teaching the people!”
Then the captain went with the officers and brought them back—though not by force, for they were afraid of being stoned by the people.
Having brought them, they stood them before the Sanhedrin. The high priest questioned them,
saying, “We gave you strict orders not to teach in this name, yet look—you have filled Jerusalem with your teaching and you intend to bring this man’s blood upon us.”
But Peter and the apostles answered, “It is necessary to obey God as the ultimate authority rather than men.
The God of our fathers raised Jesus, whom you disposed of by hanging him on a tree.
God exalted this man to his right hand as Pioneer-Leader and Savior, to give repentance to Israel and forgiveness of sins.
And we are witnesses of these matters, as is the Holy Spirit, whom God has given to those who obey him as their leader.”
When they heard this, they were sawn with rage and wanted to execute them.
But a certain Pharisee in the Sanhedrin named Gamaliel, a teacher of the law honored by all the people, stood up and ordered that the men be put outside for a short time.
He said to them, “Men of Israel, take care regarding what you are about to do to these men.
For some time ago Theudas rose up, claiming to be somebody, and a number of men, about four hundred, joined him. He was killed, and all who were persuaded by him were dispersed and came to nothing.
After him, Judas the Galilean rose up in the days of the census and drew people away after him. He also perished, and all who were persuaded by him were scattered.
So in the present case, I tell you: keep away from these men and let them alone. For if this plan or this work is of human origin, it will be overthrown;
but if it is from God, you will not be able to overthrow them—you might even be found to be warring against God.” They were persuaded by him.
After calling the apostles in and flogging them, they ordered them not to speak in the name of Jesus and released them.
So they went out from the presence of the Sanhedrin, rejoicing that they had been considered worthy to be dishonored for the sake of the Name.
And every day, in the temple courts and from house to house, they did not cease teaching and proclaiming the good news that Jesus is the Anointed One.

chapters.notes:
**"Secretly misappropriated" (v. 2, 3)**: The Greek *enosphisato* carries the sense of siphoning off or embezzling funds for oneself. Significantly, this is the same word used in the Septuagint (Joshua 7:1) to describe Achan’s theft of the "devoted things." For an audience steeped in the Hebrew scriptures, this would immediately signal that Ananias’s sin was a violation of the community's holiness, mirroring the sin that brought judgment upon early Israel.

**"Breathed his last" (v. 5, 10)**: The Greek *exepsyxen* is a specific term for expiring or "giving up the ghost." It evokes a sense of sudden, divine judicial intervention rather than a natural medical collapse.

**"Assembly" (v. 11)**: *Ekklēsia* is often translated "church," but in this early context, it retains the sense of the "assembly" of Israel. This is the first time the word appears in the book of Acts.

**"Sect" (v. 17)**: *Hairesis* refers to a school of thought or a faction within a larger religion. While it is the root of the English "heresy," here it describes the Sadducees as a distinct party or "denomination" within Judaism.

**"The words of this Life" (v. 20)**: This is a Semitic idiom. "This Life" refers to the new era of resurrection life inaugurated by Jesus. It is not just "lifestyle," but the reality of the Messianic age.

**"Obey God as the ultimate authority" (v. 29, 32)**: The verb *peitharchein* specifically means to obey a ruler or an authority. It is more specific than the general word for "obey" (*hypakouō*). It emphasizes a conflict of jurisdictions—the apostles are choosing the higher government (God) over the lower one (the Sanhedrin).

**"Hanging him on a tree" (v. 30)**: The use of *xylou* (wood/tree) instead of "cross" is a deliberate allusion to Deuteronomy 21:22-23. To a Jewish audience, this emphasized the "curse" associated with the manner of Jesus's death, which Peter then contrasts with God’s exaltation of him.

**"Pioneer-Leader" (v. 31)**: *Archēgos* means a founder, a pathfinder, or a prince who leads the way. It implies Jesus is the one who opens the path to salvation for others to follow.

**"Sawn with rage" (v. 33)**: The Greek *dieprionto* literally means "they were sawn through." Most translations use "cut to the heart," but the Greek describes a much more violent, visceral agitation than the "piercing" of the heart found in Acts 2:37. It is the friction of extreme internal fury.

**"Warring against God" (v. 39)**: The Greek *theomachoi* is a powerful compound word. In Greek literature (like Euripides’ *Bacchae*), a *theomachos* is someone who foolishly attempts to fight against the inescapable will of a god. Gamaliel is warning the council of the cosmic danger of their actions.

**"The Anointed One" (v. 42)**: The Greek *ton christon Iēsoun* is translated here with the meaning of the title "Christ" (Messiah). The apostles were not just teaching "Jesus Christ" as a name, but were proclaiming the core claim that Jesus is indeed the promised Messiah.

verses.text: During those days, as the disciples were increasing in number, a complaint broke out among the Greek-speaking Jews against the local Aramaic-speaking Jews, because their widows were being overlooked in the daily distribution of food.
So the Twelve summoned the whole assembly of the disciples and said, "It is not right for us to neglect the message of God in order to serve at tables.
Therefore, brothers, look for seven men from among yourselves who are well-regarded, full of the Spirit and wisdom, whom we will appoint to this responsibility.
But we will devote ourselves to prayer and to the service of the message."

This proposal was pleasing to the entire assembly. They chose Stephen, a man full of faith and the Holy Spirit, along with Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolaus, a convert to Judaism from Antioch.
They presented these men to the apostles, who prayed and laid their hands on them.
And so the message of God continued to spread. The number of disciples in Jerusalem increased dramatically, and a large crowd of priests began to obey the faith.
Now Stephen, full of grace and power, was performing great wonders and signs among the people.

However, resistance arose from some members of the "Synagogue of the Freedmen" (as it was called)—comprised of Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and those from Cilicia and Asia. They began debating with Stephen,
but they were not strong enough to withstand the wisdom and the Spirit by which he spoke.
Then they secretly instigated men to say, "We heard him speaking blasphemous words against Moses and against God."
They stirred up the people, the elders, and the scholars of the Law; they confronted Stephen, seized him, and brought him before the High Council.
They put forward false witnesses who said, "This man never stops speaking against this holy place and the Law.
For we have heard him saying that this Jesus the Nazarene will destroy this place and will change the customs that Moses handed down to us."
As everyone sitting in the Council stared intently at Stephen, they saw that his face looked like the face of an angel.

chapters.notes:
**"Greek-speaking Jews / Aramaic-speaking Jews" (v. 1)**: The Greek terms *Hellēnistōn* and *Hebraious* refer to a cultural and linguistic division within the early Jewish-Christian community. The "Hellenists" were Jews from the Diaspora who spoke Greek and adopted more Greek customs, while the "Hebrews" were local Judean Jews who spoke Aramaic (the "Hebrew" language of the period) and were more culturally traditional.

**"Distribution of food / Service" (v. 1, 2, 4)**: The Greek *diakonia* (noun) and *diakonein* (verb) refer to practical service. While often translated as "ministry," it carries the concrete sense of "waiting on tables" or "distributing resources." The author uses the same root for both the food distribution (v. 1) and the "service of the message" (v. 4), suggesting that both are vital forms of service, though the apostles must prioritize the latter.

**"Message of God" (v. 2, 4, 7)**: The Greek *logos* is often translated as "Word," but in the context of Acts, it specifically refers to the proclamation or the "message" concerning Jesus and the Kingdom of God.

**"Responsibility" (v. 3)**: The Greek *chreias* literally means "need" or "necessity," but in this administrative context, it refers to the "task," "duty," or "office" created to meet that need.

**"Convert to Judaism" (v. 5)**: The Greek *prosēlyton* refers to a Gentile who had undergone full conversion to Judaism, including circumcision and the keeping of the Law.

**"Synagogue of the Freedmen" (v. 9)**: *Libertinōn* refers to "Freedmen"—former slaves (or their descendants) who had been granted Roman liberty. Many Jews had been taken to Rome as captives in previous decades and later returned to Jerusalem.

**"Scholars of the Law" (v. 12)**: The *grammateis* (traditionally "scribes") were the professional class of experts in the interpretation and teaching of the Torah.

**"High Council" (v. 12, 15)**: The *synedrion* (Sanhedrin) was the supreme judicial and religious legal body in Jerusalem.

**"Face of an angel" (v. 15)**: This description evokes the "shining face" of Moses after encountering God on Sinai (Exodus 34). The author intends to show that while Stephen is accused of speaking against Moses, he actually reflects the same divine glory that Moses did.

verses.text: Then the high priest asked, “Is this the case?”
Stephen replied: “Brothers and fathers, listen to me. The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham while he was still in Mesopotamia, before he settled in Haran,
and said to him, ‘Leave your land and your relatives, and come to the land that I will show you.’
So he left the land of the Chaldeans and settled in Haran. From there, after his father died, God moved him into this land where you are now living.

Yet he gave him no inheritance in it, not even a foot’s breadth of ground. Instead, he promised to give it to him as a possession, and to his offspring after him, even though Abraham had no child at the time.
God spoke in this way: ‘His descendants will be strangers in a foreign land, and they will be enslaved and mistreated for four hundred years.
But I will judge the nation they serve as slaves,’ said God, ‘and after these things they will come out and they will worship me in this place.’

Then God gave him the covenant of circumcision; and so Abraham became the father of Isaac and circumcised him on the eighth day, and Isaac became the father of Jacob, and Jacob the father of the twelve patriarchs.
“The patriarchs, becoming jealous of Joseph, sold him into Egypt. But God was with him
and rescued him out of all his afflictions. He granted him favor and wisdom in the presence of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who appointed him governor over Egypt and over his entire household.
Then a famine came over all Egypt and Canaan, causing great suffering, and our ancestors could find no food.
But when Jacob heard there was grain in Egypt, he sent our ancestors there on their first visit.
On the second visit, Joseph made himself known to his brothers, and Joseph’s family background became clear to Pharaoh.
Then Joseph sent for his father Jacob and all his relatives, seventy-five people in all.
So Jacob went down to Egypt. There he died, as did our ancestors.
Their bodies were brought back to Shechem and laid in the tomb that Abraham had bought for a sum of silver from the sons of Hamor in Shechem.
“As the time drew near for the promise God had sworn to Abraham, the people grew and multiplied in Egypt,
until another king arose over Egypt who knew nothing of Joseph.
He exploited our people with cunning and mistreated our ancestors, forcing them to abandon their infants so they would not survive.
It was at this time that Moses was born, and he was remarkably beautiful in the sight of God. For three months he was nurtured in his father’s house;
and when he was abandoned, the daughter of Pharaoh took him up and raised him as her own son.
So Moses was educated in all the wisdom of the Egyptians and was powerful in his words and his deeds.
“When he was forty years old, it entered his heart to visit his brothers, the sons of Israel.
Seeing one of them being mistreated, he defended him and avenged the man who was being oppressed by striking down the Egyptian.
He assumed his brothers would understand that God was granting them deliverance through his hand, but they did not understand.
The next day he appeared to them as they were fighting and tried to reconcile them in peace, saying, ‘Men, you are brothers; why are you mistreating one another?’
But the man who was mistreating his neighbor pushed Moses away, saying, ‘Who appointed you a ruler and a judge over us?
Do you want to kill me the way you killed the Egyptian yesterday?’
At this remark, Moses fled and became a stranger in the land of Midian, where he became the father of two sons.
“When forty years had passed, an angel appeared to him in the wilderness of Mount Sinai in the flame of a burning bush.
When Moses saw it, he was amazed at the sight. As he approached to look more closely, the voice of the Lord came:
‘I am the God of your fathers—the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’ Moses began to tremble with fear and did not dare to look.
The Lord said to him, ‘Take the sandals off your feet, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.
I have surely seen the mistreatment of my people in Egypt and have heard their groaning, and I have come down to rescue them. Now come, I will send you to Egypt.’
“This Moses, whom they rejected by saying, ‘Who appointed you a ruler and a judge?’—this very man God sent as both ruler and liberator by the hand of the angel who appeared to him in the bush.
This man led them out, performing wonders and signs in the land of Egypt, at the Red Sea, and in the wilderness for forty years.
This is the Moses who said to the sons of Israel, ‘God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your brothers.’
This is the one who was in the assembly in the wilderness with the angel who spoke to him on Mount Sinai and with our ancestors; he received living utterances to give to us.
“Our ancestors were unwilling to be obedient to him; instead, they pushed him aside and in their hearts they turned back to Egypt,
saying to Aaron, ‘Make gods for us who will go before us. As for this Moses who led us out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him.’
They made a calf in those days and offered a sacrifice to the idol, and they began to celebrate the works of their own hands.

But God turned away and gave them over to worship the host of heaven, just as it is written in the book of the prophets: ‘Did you bring me slain beasts and sacrifices for forty years in the wilderness, O house of Israel?
No, you took up the tent of Moloch and the star of your god Rephan, the images you made to worship. Therefore, I will deport you beyond Babylon.’
“Our ancestors had the tent of the testimony in the wilderness, just as the one speaking to Moses directed him to make it according to the pattern he had seen.
Our ancestors in turn received it and brought it in with Joshua when they took possession of the nations that God drove out before our ancestors. It remained until the days of David,
who found favor in the sight of God and asked to find a dwelling place for the God of Jacob.
But it was Solomon who built a house for him.
However, the Most High does not dwell in handmade structures, as the prophet says:
‘Heaven is my throne, and the earth is a footstool for my feet. What kind of house will you build for me, says the Lord, or what is the place of my rest?
Did not my hand make all these things?’
“You stiff-necked people, uncircumcised in hearts and ears! You are always resisting the Holy Spirit. As your ancestors did, so do you.
Which of the prophets did your ancestors not persecute? They even killed those who announced in advance the coming of the Righteous One, whose betrayers and murderers you have now become—
you who received the law as ordained by angels, yet did not keep it.”
When they heard these things, they were cut to the quick and began gnashing their teeth at him.
But Stephen, full of the Holy Spirit, gazed into heaven and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing at the right hand of God.
He said, “Look! I see the heavens opened and the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God.”
But they let out a loud cry, covered their ears, and rushed at him with one purpose.
They dragged him out of the city and began to stone him. The witnesses laid their coats at the feet of a young man named Saul.
As they were stoning him, Stephen called out, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”
Then falling to his knees, he cried out with a loud voice, “Lord, do not hold this sin against them.” And after saying this, he fell asleep.

chapters.notes:
**"God of glory" (v. 2)**: This title (Ps 29:3) emphasizes God's majesty and presence outside the Temple, a key theme in Stephen's defense.

**"Remarkably beautiful in the sight of God" (v. 20)**: The Greek *asteios tō theō* is often translated "beautiful before God" or "fair to God." In Koine Greek, this dative construction serves as a superlative, suggesting Moses possessed a divine or extraordinary beauty/favor from birth.

**"Liberator" (v. 35)**: The Greek *lytrōtēn* is often rendered "redeemer," but in this context—contrasted with "ruler and judge"—it emphasizes Moses's role as the one who effected the physical and political liberation of Israel from Egypt.

**"Living utterances" (v. 38)**: *logia zōnta* refers to the commands of God. "Utterances" captures the sense of spoken oracles that carry the vital, active power of God, rather than static "words."

**"Handmade structures" (v. 48)**: *cheiropoiētois* is a loaded term. In the Septuagint, it almost exclusively refers to idols ("things made with hands"). By applying it to the Temple, Stephen makes a provocative connection between the Judean fixation on the Temple building and the idolatry of their ancestors.

**"Cut to the quick" (v. 54)**: The verb *dieprionto* literally means "to be sawn through." It describes a visceral, agonizing emotional reaction—somewhere between extreme conviction and murderous rage.

**"Fell asleep" (v. 60)**: *ekoimēthē* is the standard New Testament euphemism for the death of a believer, emphasizing the hope of resurrection. It stands in stark contrast to the violence of the preceding scene.

verses.text: Saul was in full agreement with his execution. On that day, a severe persecution broke out against the church in Jerusalem, and everyone was scattered throughout the regions of Judea and Samaria, except for the apostles.
Devout men buried Stephen and raised a great lamentation over him.
Saul, however, began ravaging the church; entering house after house, he dragged off both men and women and handed them over to prison.
Now those who had been scattered went from place to place proclaiming the good news of the Word.
Philip went down to a city in Samaria and began proclaiming the Messiah to them.
The crowds with one mind paid close attention to what Philip said when they heard him and saw the signs he was performing.
For many who had unclean spirits were being delivered as the spirits came out shrieking with a loud voice; many who were paralyzed or lame were also healed.
So there was great joy in that city.
Now a man named Simon had previously been practicing sorcery in the city and astounded the people of Samaria, claiming to be someone great.
Everyone, from the least to the greatest, paid close attention to him, saying, "This man is the Power of God that is called 'The Great One'."
They paid attention to him because he had astounded them for a long time with his magical arts.
But when they believed Philip as he proclaimed the good news about the kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women.
Even Simon himself believed, and after being baptized, he stayed close to Philip. He was astounded as he watched the great signs and works of power taking place.
When the apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had welcomed the word of God, they sent Peter and John to them.
When they arrived, they prayed for them so that they might receive the Holy Spirit,
for the Spirit had not yet fallen upon any of them; they had only been baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus.
Then Peter and John laid their hands on them, and they received the Holy Spirit.
When Simon saw that the Spirit was given through the laying on of the apostles' hands, he offered them money,
saying, "Give me this authority as well, so that anyone on whom I lay my hands may receive the Holy Spirit."
But Peter said to him, "May your silver perish with you, because you thought you could acquire the gift of God with money!
You have no part or portion in this matter, for your heart is not straight before God.
Repent, therefore, of this wickedness of yours, and pray to the Lord that, if possible, the intent of your heart may be forgiven you.
For I see that you are in the gall of bitterness and the chains of wickedness."
Simon answered, "Pray to the Lord for me yourselves, so that nothing of what you have said may happen to me."
So, after they had offered their testimony and spoken the word of the Lord, they started back toward Jerusalem, proclaiming the good news to many Samaritan villages along the way.
Now an angel of the Lord spoke to Philip, saying, "Get up and go toward the south on the road that goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza." (This is a desert road.)

So he got up and went. And look! There was an Ethiopian man, a eunuch and high official of Kandake, queen of the Ethiopians, who was in charge of her entire treasury. He had come to Jerusalem to worship
and was returning home. Sitting in his chariot, he was reading the prophet Isaiah.
The Spirit said to Philip, "Go over and join that chariot."
Philip ran up and heard him reading Isaiah the prophet and asked, "Do you actually understand what you are reading?"
He said, "How could I, unless someone guides me?" And he invited Philip to come up and sit with him.
Now the passage of Scripture he was reading was this: "He was led like a sheep to the slaughter, and as a lamb before its shearer is silent, so he does not open his mouth.
In his humiliation, justice was denied him. Who can describe his generation? For his life is taken away from the earth."
The eunuch said to Philip, "Please tell me, who is the prophet talking about? Himself, or someone else?"
Then Philip opened his mouth, and starting from this Scripture, he proclaimed the good news of Jesus to him.
As they were traveling along the road, they came to some water, and the eunuch said, "Look, here is water! What prevents me from being baptized?"
He ordered the chariot to stop, and both of them, Philip and the eunuch, went down into the water, and Philip baptized him.
When they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord snatched Philip away, and the eunuch saw him no longer, but went on his way rejoicing.
Philip found himself at Azotus, and as he passed through, he proclaimed the good news to all the towns until he reached Caesarea.

chapters.notes:
**"Execution" (v. 1)**: The Greek *anairesei* suggests a "removal" or a "putting away," used here in the context of the judicial or extrajudicial killing of Stephen.

**"Ravaging" (v. 3)**: *Elymaineto* is a strong verb often used in Greek literature to describe a wild animal mangling its prey or an army devastating a city. It conveys the brutal, systematic nature of Saul’s campaign.

**"The Power of God... 'The Great One'" (v. 10)**: This reflects a specific title. In the religious atmosphere of the first century, particularly in Samaria, "The Great Power" (*He Dynamis he Megale*) was understood as a name for a divine emanation or the supreme deity itself. 

**"Astounded" (vv. 9, 11, 13)**: The Greek *existēmi* is used as a deliberate literary thread. Simon "astounded" the Samaritans with magic, but then Simon himself is "astounded" by the actual power of God through Philip.

**"Gift of God" (v. 20)**: *Dōrean* emphasizes that the Spirit is a free, unmerited favor, making Simon’s attempt to "purchase" it a fundamental category error.

**"Gall of bitterness" (v. 23)**: *Cholen pikrias* refers to the bile of a venomous animal. To the original audience, this would signify a state of being "poisoned" by envy or resentment.

**"Kandake" (v. 27)**: This is not a personal name but a dynastic title (like "Pharaoh" or "Caesar") for the Queen Mother of the Kingdom of Kush (ancient Ethiopia/Nubia).

**"Do you actually understand..." (v. 30)**: There is a famous wordplay in the Greek (*ginōskeis ha anaginōskeis*) that is difficult to replicate in English. Literally: "Do you know what you are re-knowing?"

**"In his humiliation, justice was denied him" (v. 33)**: This follows the Septuagint (LXX) rendering of Isaiah 53, which differs from the Masoretic Text. The focus here is on the legal injustice and the stripping away of the sufferer's rights during his trial.

**"What prevents me..." (v. 36)**: This phrasing likely reflects an early baptismal formula or liturgical practice where the candidate’s fitness was questioned before the rite. Note that verse 37 is omitted, as it is absent from the earliest and most reliable manuscripts (P45, P74, Sinaiticus, Vaticanus).

**"Snatched away" (v. 39)**: *Hērpasen* implies a sudden, forceful removal. It is the same verb used for being "caught up" in 1 Thessalonians 4:17.

verses.text: Meanwhile Saul, still inhaling the breath of threats and murder against the disciples of the Lord, went to the high priest
and requested letters from him to the synagogues in Damascus. His purpose was that if he found any who belonged to the Way—whether men or women—he might bring them bound to Jerusalem.
As he was traveling, it happened that he was drawing near to Damascus when suddenly a light from heaven flashed around him.
He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him, “Saoul, Saoul, why are you persecuting me?”
He asked, “Who are you, Lord?” And the voice replied, “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.
But get up and enter the city, and you will be told what you must do.”
The men traveling with him stood speechless; they heard the sound of the voice but saw no one.
Saul got up from the ground, but though his eyes were wide open, he could see nothing. So they led him by the hand and brought him into Damascus.
For three days he was without sight, and he neither ate nor drank.
Now there was a certain disciple in Damascus named Ananias. The Lord said to him in a vision, “Ananias.” He replied, “Here I am, Lord.”
The Lord said to him, “Get up and go to the street called ‘Straight,’ and at the house of Judas look for a man from Tarsus named Saul. For behold, he is praying,
and in a vision he has seen a man named Ananias come in and lay hands on him so that he might regain his sight.”
But Ananias answered, “Lord, I have heard from many about this man, and how much harm he has done to your holy ones in Jerusalem.
And here he has authority from the chief priests to bind everyone who calls upon your name.”
But the Lord said to him, “Go, for this man is an instrument of my choosing, to carry my name before the nations and their kings, and before the sons of Israel.
For I myself will show him how much he must suffer for the sake of my name.”

So Ananias departed and entered the house. He laid his hands on him and said, “Saoul, my brother, the Lord—Jesus, who appeared to you on the road as you were coming—has sent me so that you may regain your sight and be filled with the Holy Spirit.”
Immediately, something like husks fell from his eyes and his sight was restored. He got up and was baptized,
and after taking food, his strength returned. He remained for some days with the disciples in Damascus,
and immediately in the synagogues he began proclaiming Jesus, saying, “This man is the Son of God.”

All who heard him were astonished and said, “Is this not the man who ravaged those in Jerusalem who call upon this name? And hasn't he come here for this very purpose—to bring them bound before the chief priests?”
But Saul grew even more capable, and he confounded the Jews living in Damascus by demonstrating conclusively that this man is the Messiah.
When many days had passed, the Jews plotted together to do away with him,
but their plot became known to Saul. They were even guarding the city gates day and night in order to kill him.
But his disciples took him by night and let him down through an opening in the wall, lowering him in a large wicker basket.
When he arrived in Jerusalem, he attempted to join the disciples, but they were all afraid of him, not believing that he was truly a disciple.

But Barnabas took hold of him and brought him to the apostles. He described to them how Saul had seen the Lord on the road and that the Lord had spoken to him, and how in Damascus he had spoken boldly in the name of Jesus.
So Saul moved freely with them in Jerusalem, speaking boldly in the name of the Lord.
He was speaking and debating with the Hellenists, but they were attempting to do away with him.
When the brothers learned of this, they brought him down to Caesarea and sent him off to Tarsus.

So the church throughout all Judea and Galilee and Samaria enjoyed a season of peace and was being built up. Walking in the fear of the Lord and in the encouragement of the Holy Spirit, it continued to multiply.
Now as Peter was traveling through all those regions, he also went down to the holy ones living in Lydda.
There he found a man named Aeneas who had been bedridden for eight years; he was paralyzed.
Peter said to him, “Aeneas, Jesus the Messiah heals you. Get up and make your own bed.” And immediately he stood up.
All those living in Lydda and the Plain of Sharon saw him, and they turned to the Lord.
In Joppa there was a certain disciple named Tabitha (which is translated as Dorcas, or "Gazelle"). She was devoted to doing good works and giving to the poor.
During those days she became ill and died. When they had washed her body, they laid her in an upstairs room.
Since Lydda was near Joppa, the disciples heard that Peter was there and sent two men to him, urging him, “Please come to us without delay.”

So Peter got up and went with them. When he arrived, they took him to the upstairs room. All the widows stood beside him weeping, showing him the tunics and cloaks that Dorcas used to make while she was still with them.
Peter sent everyone outside, knelt down, and prayed. Then, turning toward the body, he said, “Tabitha, get up.” She opened her eyes, and when she saw Peter, she sat up.
Giving her his hand, he helped her stand. Then he called the holy ones and the widows and presented her to them alive.
This became known throughout all Joppa, and many believed in the Lord.
And it happened that Peter stayed in Joppa for quite some time with a certain Simon, a tanner.

chapters.notes:
**"Inhaling the breath of..." (v. 1)**: The Greek *empneōn* suggests that Saul was "breathing in" or "breathing the air of" threats and murder. It implies an internal state where violence has become his very atmosphere.

**"The Way" (v. 2)**: This was the earliest self-designation of the Jesus movement, likely rooted in the "Way of the Lord" from Isaiah (and the LXX).

**"Saoul" (v. 4, 17)**: The Greek text switches from the Hellenized "Saulos" to the Semitic "Saoul" in the direct address. This preserves the Aramaic name sound (*Sha’ul*) that Saul would have heard in the vision and that Ananias used when speaking to him as a fellow Jew.

**"Holy ones" (v. 13, 32, 41)**: The Greek *hagioi* (often "saints") refers to those set apart for God. "Holy ones" captures the communal and covenantal identity of the early believers better than the modern ecclesiastical "saints."

**"Instrument of my choosing" (v. 15)**: Literally "a vessel of choice" (*skeuos eklogēs*). In the Hebrew/Aramaic idiom, "vessel" refers to a person used for a specific purpose by God.

**"The Messiah" (v. 22, 34)**: While *Christos* is often treated as a proper name ("Christ"), in these contexts—debating in synagogues and healing among Jews—it functions as a title referring to the expected Davidic Deliverer.

**"Large wicker basket" (v. 25)**: The word *spuris* refers specifically to a large, flexible hamper (different from the *kophinos* used in the feeding of the 5,000).

**"Hellenists" (v. 29)**: These were Greek-speaking Jews, often from the Diaspora. Their conflict with Saul is significant because he was one of them.

**"Make your own bed" (v. 34)**: The Greek *strōson seautō* literally means "spread for yourself." It is an idiom for making one's bed or preparing a couch, signifying a complete and immediate recovery from paralysis.

**"Tabitha / Dorcas" (v. 36)**: Luke provides both the Aramaic name (*Tabitha*) and the Greek translation (*Dorkas*). Both mean "Gazelle." Keeping both emphasizes the bilingual, multicultural setting of the early church.

**"Tanner" (v. 43)**: This is a socially significant detail. Tanners dealt with dead animals and were often considered ceremonially unclean or socially marginalized. Peter staying with a tanner hints at his growing openness to breaking traditional purity boundaries, which culminates in the next chapter.

verses.text: In Caesarea there was a man named Cornelius, a centurion in what was known as the Italian Cohort.
He was a devout man, a "God-fearer" along with his entire household; he performed many acts of charity for the Jewish people and was constant in his prayer to God.
One afternoon, about the ninth hour, he had a vision in which he clearly saw a messenger of God enter and say to him, “Cornelius.”
He stared at the messenger in terror and asked, “What is it, lord?” The messenger replied, “Your prayers and your acts of charity have ascended as a memorial offering before God.
Now, send men to Joppa and summon a man named Simon, who is also called Peter.
He is staying as a guest with another Simon, a tanner, whose house is by the sea.”
When the messenger who had spoken to him departed, Cornelius called two of his household servants and a devout soldier from among his personal attendants.
After explaining everything to them, he sent them to Joppa.
The next day, as they were traveling and approaching the city, Peter went up on the flat roof of the house to pray around the sixth hour.
He became quite hungry and wanted to eat, but while the meal was being prepared, he fell into a trance.
He saw the sky opened and something like a large linen sheet coming down, being lowered by its four corners to the earth.
In it were all kinds of four-footed animals, crawling creatures of the earth, and birds of the sky.
Then a voice came to him: “Get up, Peter; slaughter and eat!”
But Peter said, “By no means, Lord! For I have never eaten anything profane or ritually unclean.”
The voice spoke to him again, a second time: “What God has made clean, you must not call profane.”
This happened three times, and then the object was immediately taken up into heaven.
While Peter was still deeply perplexed about what the vision he had seen might mean, the men sent by Cornelius—having asked their way to Simon’s house—stood at the gate.
They called out to ask if Simon, known as Peter, was staying there as a guest.
While Peter was still mulling over the vision, the Spirit said to him, “Look, men are searching for you.
Get up, go downstairs, and go with them without hesitation, because I myself have sent them.”
So Peter went down to the men and said, “I am the one you are looking for. For what reason have you come?”

They replied, “Cornelius, a centurion—a righteous and God-fearing man who is well-regarded by the entire Jewish nation—was divinely instructed by a holy messenger to summon you to his house so he could hear a message from you.”
So Peter invited them in and gave them lodging. The next day he got up and went with them, and some of the brothers from Joppa accompanied him.
The following day he entered Caesarea. Cornelius was expecting them and had invited his relatives and close friends.
When Peter entered, Cornelius met him, fell at his feet, and bowed down in reverence.
But Peter raised him up, saying, “Stand up; I too am only a human being.”
As he talked with him, Peter went inside and found many people gathered.

He said to them, “You yourselves know how taboo it is for a Jewish man to associate closely with or visit a foreigner. But God has shown me that I should call no human being profane or ritually unclean.
This is why I came without objection when I was sent for. So I ask, for what reason did you send for me?”
Cornelius replied, “Four days ago at this very hour, the ninth hour, I was praying in my house. Suddenly a man stood before me in radiant clothing
and said, ‘Cornelius, your prayer has been heard and your acts of charity have been remembered before God.
Send therefore to Joppa and summon Simon, who is called Peter; he is staying as a guest in the house of Simon, a tanner, by the sea.’
So I sent for you immediately, and it was good of you to come. Now we are all here in the presence of God to hear everything the Lord has commanded you to say.”
Then Peter began to speak: “I truly understand now that God does not show favoritism based on status.
Instead, in every nation, the one who fears him and does what is right is acceptable to him.
This is the message he sent to the sons of Israel, proclaiming the good news of peace through Jesus Christ—he is Lord of all.
You know the events that took place throughout all Judea, beginning from Galilee after the immersion that John proclaimed:
how God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Spirit and with power, and how he went about doing good as a benefactor and healing all who were tyrannized by the devil, because God was with him.
“We are witnesses of all he did both in the Judean countryside and in Jerusalem. They put him to death by hanging him on a tree,
but God raised him on the third day and allowed him to be clearly seen—
not by all the people, but by witnesses previously chosen by God, by us, who ate and drank with him after he rose from the dead.
And he commanded us to preach to the people and to testify solemnly that he is the one designated by God as judge of the living and the dead.
To him all the prophets bear witness, that everyone who believes in him receives a release from sins through his name.”
While Peter was still speaking these words, the Holy Spirit fell upon all who were listening to the message.
The circumcised believers who had come with Peter were astonished that the gift of the Holy Spirit had been poured out even on the Gentiles,
for they heard them speaking in tongues and extolling the greatness of God. Then Peter responded,
“Can anyone withhold the water for baptizing these people who have received the Holy Spirit just as we did?”
So he directed that they be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ. Then they asked him to stay for several days.

chapters.notes:
**"God-fearer" (v. 2, 22)**: The Greek *phoboumenos ton theon* was a technical term in the first century for Gentiles who worshipped the God of Israel and followed Jewish ethical laws but had not undergone circumcision or full conversion to Judaism.

**"Memorial offering" (v. 4, 31)**: The Greek *mnēmosynon* corresponds to the Hebrew *azkarah*, a specific type of sacrificial offering in the Septuagint (Leviticus 2:2). This signals to the reader that Cornelius’s piety is being treated by God as a legitimate sacrifice, despite his Gentile status.

**"Profane or ritually unclean" (v. 14, 28)**: Peter uses two distinct terms: *koinon* (common/profane) and *akatharton* (ritually unclean). *Koinon* refers to things that are "common" to the world and thus not set apart for God's use, while *akatharton* refers to things explicitly forbidden by the Levitical law.

**"Without hesitation" (v. 20)**: The verb *diakrinomenos* carries the sense of "making a distinction" or "doubting." In this context, it refers to the inner conflict Peter would feel about violating social-religious boundaries.

**"Taboo" (v. 28)**: The Greek *athemiton* refers to that which is "unlawful" not necessarily by statutory law, but by established religious custom and social norms. In the Roman world, it often referred to things that were "abominable" or "taboo."

**"Does not show favoritism based on status" (v. 34)**: The Greek *prosōpolēmptēs* is a literal rendering of a Hebrew idiom meaning "to lift the face." It refers to a judge who shows partiality to someone based on their social standing or appearance.

**"Benefactor" (v. 38)**: The participle *euergetōn* evokes the "Benefactor" (*Euergetes*) titles common among Hellenistic rulers. Luke is contrasting Jesus’s actual "doing of good" with the self-proclaimed titles of worldly kings.

**"Tyrannized" (v. 38)**: The verb *katadynasteuomenous* is stronger than "oppressed"; it implies being under the harsh, arbitrary rule of a potentate or tyrant.

**"Hanging him on a tree" (v. 39)**: While *xylon* can mean "wood" or "cross," the use of "tree" preserves the allusion to Deuteronomy 21:22–23, which discusses the curse of one hanged on a tree—a point of great significance in early Jewish-Christian preaching.

**"Release from sins" (v. 43)**: The Greek *aphesin* is often translated as "forgiveness," but its primary sense is "release," "dismissal," or "liberation" (as from a debt or captivity). It carries a more active sense of being set free than the English "forgiveness" usually implies.

verses.text: Now the apostles and the brothers who were throughout Judea heard that the nations had also welcomed the word of God.
So when Peter went up to Jerusalem, the circumcision faction took issue with him,
saying, “You entered the house of uncircumcised men and even ate with them!”
But Peter began to explain the matter to them in sequence:

“I was in the city of Joppa praying, and in a visionary state I saw a vision: something like a large linen sheet was descending, being lowered from heaven by its four corners, and it came right down to me.
Looking closely at it, I observed and saw the four-footed animals of the earth, the wild beasts, the reptiles, and the birds of the sky.
I also heard a voice saying to me, ‘Get up, Peter; sacrifice and eat.’
But I said, ‘Not at all, Lord! For nothing ritually common or impure has ever entered my mouth.’
But a voice from heaven answered a second time, ‘What God has made clean, you must not call common.’
This happened three times, and then everything was pulled back up into heaven.
“And look, at that very moment, three men stood at the house where we were, having been sent to me from Caesarea.
The Spirit told me to go with them without making any distinction. These six brothers also went with me, and we entered the man’s house.
He reported to us how he had seen the angel standing in his house and saying, ‘Send to Joppa and summon Simon, the one nicknamed Peter;
he will speak words to you by which you will be saved, you and your entire household.’
As I began to speak, the Holy Spirit fell upon them just as he did upon us at the beginning.
Then I remembered the word of the Lord, how he used to say, ‘John baptized with water, but you will be baptized in the Holy Spirit.’
If, therefore, God gave them the same gift he gave to us when we believed in the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I to be able to hinder God?”
When they heard these things, they were silenced; and they glorified God, saying, “So then, God has granted even to the nations the repentance that leads to life.”
Now those who had been scattered by the oppression that arose over Stephen traveled as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch, speaking the word to no one except Jews.
But there were some of them—men from Cyprus and Cyrene—who, upon coming to Antioch, began speaking to the Greeks as well, announcing the good news of the Lord Jesus.
The hand of the Lord was with them, and a great number who believed turned to the Lord.
The report about them reached the ears of the church in Jerusalem, and they sent Barnabas out to Antioch.
When he arrived and saw the grace of God, he was glad and began encouraging them all to remain true to the Lord with a fixed purpose of heart,
for he was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit and of faith. And a significant crowd was added to the Lord.
Then Barnabas went to Tarsus to look for Saul,

and when he found him, he brought him to Antioch. For an entire year they met together within the church and taught a significant crowd. It was in Antioch that the disciples were first given the name “Christians.”
In those days, prophets came down from Jerusalem to Antioch.
One of them, named Agabus, stood up and indicated through the Spirit that a severe famine was about to come over the entire inhabited world—which indeed happened during the reign of Claudius.
So the disciples, according to their individual means, determined to send a relief contribution to the brothers living in Judea.
This they did, sending it to the elders by the hand of Barnabas and Saul.

chapters.notes:
**"The nations" (v. 1, 18)**: The Greek *ethnē* is often translated as "Gentiles," but in a first-century Jewish context, it refers to the non-Jewish nations. This carries the weight of the Abrahamic promise—that through his seed, all the *nations* would be blessed.

**"The circumcision faction" (v. 2)**: *Hoi ek peritomēs* (those of the circumcision) refers specifically to Jewish believers who maintained that circumcision and adherence to the Mosaic Law were necessary for inclusion in the covenant community.

**"Ritually common" (v. 8, 9)**: The Greek *koinon* means "common" or "shared," but in the context of Jewish dietary laws, it refers to things that are "profane" or not set apart as holy/kosher. It is distinct from *akatharton* (impure/unclean), though they are often paired.

**"Without making any distinction" (v. 12)**: The verb *diakrinō* is used here as a wordplay. In verse 2, the critics "took issue" (*diekrinonto*) with Peter, effectively "creating a division" or "making a distinction" based on legal purity. The Spirit commands Peter to do the opposite—to move toward the Gentiles without creating such a separation.

**"Oppression" (v. 19)**: The Greek *thlipsis* (tribulation, affliction) refers to the intense pressure and persecution following Stephen's martyrdom.

**"Greeks" (v. 20)**: While some manuscripts read *Hellēnistas* (Hellenists/Greek-speaking Jews), the context of the passage—contrasting them with those who spoke "to no one except Jews" in verse 19—strongly suggests the author intended *Hellēnas* (Greeks/Gentiles).

**"Announcing the good news" (v. 20)**: The verb *euangelizō* is more specific than simply "preaching." It refers to the proclamation of a victory or a royal announcement.

**"Given the name 'Christians'" (v. 26)**: The Greek *chrēmatisai* often carries the sense of an official designation, a public name, or even a divine decree. The suffix *-ianos* in *Christianoi* is a Latinism (like *Caesarianos*), denoting "those of the party of Christ." It likely began as a label applied by outsiders to identify this new group.

**"The entire inhabited world" (v. 28)**: The Greek *oikoumenē* refers specifically to the Roman world—the civilized, "inhabited" world of the empire—rather than the entire physical globe.

**"Relief contribution" (v. 29)**: *Diakonia* is often translated as "ministry" or "service." In this context, it refers to the practical, material service of a financial collection for the poor.

verses.text: Around that time, King Herod began a violent campaign against certain members of the assembly of believers.
He executed James, the brother of John, with the sword.
When he saw that this was popular with the Judeans, he proceeded to arrest Peter as well. This occurred during the festival of Unleavened Bread.

After seizing him, Herod put him in prison, handing him over to four squads of four soldiers each to guard him. His intention was to bring him out for a public trial before the people after the Passover.
So Peter was kept under guard in the prison, while the assembly of believers prayed fervently to God on his behalf.
On the very night before Herod was to bring him forward for trial, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with two chains, while sentries in front of the door kept watch over the prison.

Suddenly, a messenger of the Lord stood there, and a light shone in the cell. Striking Peter on the side, the messenger woke him, saying, “Get up quickly!” At that moment, the chains fell from his wrists.
