Then the messenger said to him, “Put on your belt and tie your sandals.” Peter did so. The messenger said to him, “Wrap your cloak around you and follow me.”
Peter went out and followed him, yet he did not realize that what was happening through the messenger was real; he thought he was seeing a vision.

They passed the first guard post and then the second, and they came to the iron gate leading into the city. It opened for them automatically. After they went out and walked the length of one street, the messenger suddenly left him.
When Peter came to his senses, he said, “Now I know for certain that the Lord sent his messenger and rescued me from the hand of Herod and from everything the Judean people were expecting.”
Once he realized this, he went to the house of Mary, the mother of John (also known as Mark), where many had gathered and were praying.
When Peter knocked at the door of the outer gateway, a servant girl named Rhoda came to answer.
Recognizing Peter’s voice, she was so overcome with joy that she did not open the gate, but instead ran inside and announced that Peter was standing at the gateway.
They said to her, “You are out of your mind!” But she kept insisting it was so. They said, “It must be his angel.”
Meanwhile, Peter continued knocking; when they finally opened the door and saw him, they were astonished.

Motioning to them with his hand to be silent, he described to them how the Lord had led him out of the prison. He said, “Report these things to James and to the brothers.” Then he left and went to another place.
At daybreak, there was no small commotion among the soldiers as to what had become of Peter.
After Herod searched for him and did not find him, he interrogated the guards and ordered them to be led away to execution. Then Herod went down from Judea to Caesarea and stayed there.

Now Herod had been in a state of fury against the people of Tyre and Sidon. They came to him with a unified front, and after winning over Blastus, the king’s personal chamberlain, they sued for peace, because their region depended on the king’s country for its food supply.
On an appointed day, Herod put on his royal robes, sat upon the public dais, and delivered a speech to them.
The assembled crowd began shouting, “The voice of a god, and not of a man!”
Immediately, a messenger of the Lord struck him down because he did not give the glory to God; he was eaten by worms and breathed his last.
But the word of God continued to grow and multiply.
And Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem after they had fulfilled their mission of service, taking with them John, who was called Mark.

chapters.notes:
**"Assembly of believers" (v. 1, 5)**: The Greek *ekklēsia* refers to a gathering or assembly. Translating it as "church" often carries modern institutional or architectural baggage that would be foreign to the first-century reader.

**"Proceeded to" (v. 3)**: The Greek *prosetheto* ("he added to") is a Semitic idiom (reflecting an Aramaic/Hebrew substratum) used to describe a sequence of actions.

**"Public trial" (v. 4)**: The Greek *anagagein* ("to lead up") in a legal context often refers to bringing a prisoner up to a higher place (like a dais or *bema*) for a formal public trial or sentencing.

**"Cell" (v. 7)**: The word *oikēmati* literally means a dwelling or room, but in Attic and Koine Greek, it was a common euphemism for a prison cell.

**"Automatically" (v. 10)**: The Greek *automatē* is the direct root of the English word. It denotes something that moves by its own impulse or power.

**"His angel" (v. 15)**: This reflects a common first-century Jewish belief (found in Second Temple literature) that individuals had a guardian angel who could take on their physical appearance.

**"James" (v. 17)**: This refers to James the brother of Jesus, who by this point had emerged as the leader of the Jerusalem community. The James mentioned in verse 2 was the son of Zebedee.

**"Led away to execution" (v. 19)**: The Greek *apachthēnai* ("to be led away") was a standard technical term for leading a condemned prisoner to execution.

**"Public dais" (v. 21)**: The *bēma* was a raised platform or judgment seat from which officials addressed the public or handed down rulings.

**"Eaten by worms" (v. 23)**: The term *skōlēkobrōtos* is a graphic medical description used in antiquity (e.g., by Herodotus and Josephus) to describe a divine judgment involving internal parasites or gangrene.

**"Mission of service" (v. 25)**: The Greek *diakonian* refers to the specific task of bringing famine relief funds from Antioch to Jerusalem (as mentioned in Acts 11:29-30).

verses.text: Now in the church at Antioch there were prophets and teachers: Barnabas, Simeon who was called “Niger,” Lucius the Cyrenian, Manaen (who had been brought up with Herod the tetrarch), and Saul.
While they were worshiping the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, “Set apart for me Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them.”
Then, after fasting and praying, they laid their hands on them and sent them off.
So, being sent out by the Holy Spirit, they went down to Seleucia, and from there they sailed to Cyprus.
When they arrived in Salamis, they began proclaiming the word of God in the Jewish synagogues; they also had John as their assistant.
When they had gone through the whole island as far as Paphos, they found a certain man—a sorcerer and Jewish false prophet named Bar-Jesus.
He was an associate of the proconsul, Sergius Paulus, a man of keen intelligence. The proconsul summoned Barnabas and Saul, for he was eager to hear the word of God.
But Elymas the sorcerer (for that is how his name is translated) opposed them, trying to turn the proconsul away from the faith.
But Saul, also known as Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, looked him straight in the eye
and said, “You son of the devil, full of every kind of deceit and fraud! You enemy of all that is right, will you never stop distorting the straight paths of the Lord?

Now look: the hand of the Lord is against you, and you will be blind, unable to see the sun for a time.” Immediately a mist and darkness fell over him, and he groped about, seeking people to lead him by the hand.
When the proconsul saw what had happened, he believed, for he was struck with awe at the teaching about the Lord.
Paul and his companions put out to sea from Paphos and came to Perga in Pamphylia; but John left them and returned to Jerusalem.
They, however, went on from Perga and arrived at Pisidian Antioch. On the Sabbath day, they entered the synagogue and took a seat.
After the reading of the Law and the Prophets, the synagogue leaders sent word to them, saying, “Brothers, if you have any word of encouragement for the people, speak it.”
So Paul stood up, motioned with his hand, and said: “Men of Israel and you God-fearing Gentiles, listen!
The God of this people Israel chose our fathers and made the people great during their stay in the land of Egypt; then with an uplifted arm he led them out of it.
For a period of about forty years, he endured their behavior in the wilderness.
After destroying seven nations in the land of Canaan, he gave them their land as an inheritance.
All this took about four hundred and fifty years. After that, he gave them judges until the time of Samuel the prophet.
Then they asked for a king, and God gave them Saul son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, for forty years.
After removing him, he raised up David to be their king, about whom he testified: ‘I have found David son of Jesse to be a man after my own heart, who will do all my will.’
From this man’s seed, according to the promise, God has brought to Israel a Savior, Jesus.
Before his coming, John had publicly proclaimed a baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.
And as John was finishing his course, he would say, ‘What do you suppose I am? I am not he. No, but look: one is coming after me whose sandal I am not worthy to untie.’
Brothers, sons of the family of Abraham and those among you who fear God, it is to us that the message of this salvation has been sent.
For those who live in Jerusalem and their rulers did not recognize him; by condemning him, they fulfilled the voices of the prophets that are read every Sabbath.
Though they found no basis for a death sentence, they asked Pilate to have him executed.
When they had carried out everything written about him, they took him down from the tree and laid him in a tomb.
But God raised him from the dead!
For many days he appeared to those who had come up with him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are now his witnesses to the people.
And we are preaching the Good News to you: what God promised to our fathers,
he has fulfilled for us, their children, by raising Jesus—as it is also written in the second Psalm: ‘You are my Son; today I have become your Father.’
As for the fact that he raised him from the dead, never again to return to decay, he spoke in this way: ‘I will give you the holy and reliable promises made to David.’
Therefore he also says in another Psalm: ‘You will not allow your Holy One to see decay.’
For David, after serving the purpose of God in his own generation, fell asleep; he was buried with his fathers and saw decay.
But the one whom God raised did not see decay.
Therefore, let it be known to you, brothers, that through this man forgiveness of sins is proclaimed to you.
From all the things from which you could not be acquitted by the law of Moses, everyone who believes is acquitted in him.
Take care, then, that what was said in the prophets does not happen to you:
‘Look, you scoffers, be amazed and perish! For I am doing a work in your days, a work you will never believe, even if someone explains it to you in detail.’”
As Paul and Barnabas were leaving, the people kept begging them to speak these same words to them on the following Sabbath.

When the synagogue assembly broke up, many of the Jews and devout converts to Judaism followed Paul and Barnabas, who, in their conversations with them, urged them to remain constant in the grace of God.
On the next Sabbath, almost the whole city gathered to hear the word of the Lord.
But when the Jews saw the crowds, they were filled with burning jealousy and began to contradict what Paul was saying, slandering him.

Then Paul and Barnabas spoke out boldly: “It was necessary that the word of God be spoken to you first. Since you reject it and judge yourselves unworthy of eternal life, look—we are turning to the Gentiles.
For this is what the Lord has commanded us: ‘I have made you a light for the nations, that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth.’”
When the Gentiles heard this, they began to rejoice and glorify the word of the Lord, and all who were appointed to eternal life believed.
So the word of the Lord spread throughout the entire region.
But the Jews incited the prominent women of high standing and the leading men of the city; they stirred up a persecution against Paul and Barnabas and drove them out of their district.
So they shook the dust off their feet against them and went to Iconium.
And the disciples were filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.

chapters.notes:
**"Brought up with" (v. 1)**: The Greek *syntrophos* can mean a foster-brother or a close childhood companion. Given that Herod Antipas was a member of the royal household, this highlights the high social status of the early leaders in the Antiochian church.

**"Worshiping" (v. 2)**: The Greek *leitourgountōn* refers to the performance of religious service or ritual. While often associated with the "liturgy" of the temple, here it describes the communal prayer and service of the Christian leaders.

**"Sorcerer" (v. 6, 8)**: The Greek *magos* carries a range of meanings from "wise man" (as in Matthew 2) to "charlatan/sorcerer." In the context of Acts, where Luke contrasts the power of the Spirit with magic (e.g., Simon Magus in ch. 8), it is clearly pejorative.

**"Endured their behavior" (v. 18)**: There is a famous textual variant here between *etrophophorēsen* ("carried them like a nurse") and *etropophorēsen* ("endured their manners/disposition"). The SBLGNT follows the latter, which alludes to the Israelites' legendary rebelliousness in the wilderness.

**"Tree" (v. 29)**: The Greek *xylou* literally means "wood" or "tree." Luke uses this term to evoke the Deuteronomy 21:23 curse of one "hanged on a tree," a crucial theme in early Jewish-Christian apologetics regarding the crucifixion.

**"Decay" (vv. 34-37)**: The Greek *diaphthora* refers to the physical decomposition of a corpse. Paul’s argument hinges on the contrast between David, whose body underwent corruption, and Jesus, who was raised before decomposition could occur, fulfilling Psalm 16.

**"Acquitted" (v. 39)**: The Greek *dikaioō* is the verb often translated as "justify." In this legal context—contrasting what the Law of Moses could and could not do—it carries the sense of being "set right" or "acquitted" of a legal charge.

**"Appointed" (v. 48)**: The Greek *tetagmenoi* is a military or administrative term meaning "assigned," "ordered," or "designated." It suggests a divine ordering behind the Gentiles' response.

verses.text: In Iconium, the same thing happened: they entered the Jewish synagogue together and spoke in such a way that a great number of both Jews and Greeks believed.
But the Jews who refused to be persuaded stirred up the Gentiles and embittered their minds against the brothers.

Nevertheless, they stayed there for a long time, speaking boldly in reliance on the Lord, who bore witness to the message of his grace by granting signs and wonders to be performed through their hands.
The population of the city was divided; some sided with the Jews and others with the apostles.
When an attempt was made by both Gentiles and Jews, along with their leaders, to mistreat and stone them,
the apostles became aware of it and fled to the Lycaonian cities of Lystra and Derbe and the surrounding region.
There, they continued to announce the Good News.
In Lystra, a man was sitting who had no strength in his feet. He had been lame from his mother’s womb and had never walked.
He was listening to Paul speak. Paul looked at him intently and, seeing that he had the faith to be restored to wholeness,
said with a loud voice, "Stand up straight on your feet!" The man leaped up and began to walk.
When the crowds saw what Paul had done, they raised their voices in the Lycaonian language, saying, "The gods have taken human form and come down to us!"
They began calling Barnabas 'Zeus' and Paul 'Hermes,' since he was the lead speaker.
The priest of the temple of Zeus-Before-the-City brought bulls and flower wreaths to the gates and, with the crowds, intended to offer a sacrifice.
When the apostles Barnabas and Paul heard of this, they tore their clothes and rushed out into the crowd, shouting,

"Men, why are you doing these things? We are only human beings, with the same nature and vulnerabilities as you! We are announcing the Good News to you so that you may turn from these worthless things to the living God, who made the heaven, the earth, the sea, and everything in them.
In generations past, he allowed all the nations to go their own ways.
Yet he did not leave himself without witness: he showed kindness by giving you rain from heaven and fruitful seasons, filling your hearts with food and gladness."
Even with these words, they barely restrained the crowds from sacrificing to them.
Then Jews arrived from Antioch and Iconium, and after winning over the crowds, they stoned Paul and dragged him out of the city, thinking he was dead.
But after the disciples gathered around him, he got up and went back into the city. The next day, he left with Barnabas for Derbe.
After they had announced the Good News to that city and made many disciples, they returned to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch.
They were strengthening the souls of the disciples, encouraging them to remain in the faith, and saying, "We must enter the kingdom of God through many crushing pressures."
When they had appointed elders for them in every church, having prayed with fasting, they committed them to the Lord in whom they had put their trust.
Then they passed through Pisidia and came to Pamphylia.
After speaking the word in Perga, they went down to Attalia.
From there they sailed back to Antioch, where they had been commended to the grace of God for the work they had now fulfilled.
When they arrived and gathered the church together, they reported all that God had done with them and how he had opened a door of faith to the Gentiles.
And they stayed there with the disciples for a considerable time.

chapters.notes:
**"Refused to be persuaded" (v. 2)**: The Greek *apeithēsantes* suggests more than a passive lack of belief; it implies a willful rejection or disobedience to the message being presented.

**"Embittered their minds" (v. 2)**: Literally "made their souls evil." In the psychological context of the first century, the *psychē* (soul/mind) was the seat of volition and disposition. The Jews were poisoning the Gentiles' disposition toward the believers.

**"Restored to wholeness" (v. 9)**: The Greek *sōthēnai* is often translated as "saved" or "healed." In this context, it carries the holistic sense of being made "whole" or "sound"—both physically and spiritually.

**"Zeus-Before-the-City" (v. 13)**: This refers to the temple of *Zeus Propylaios* (Zeus before the gates). It was common in Hellenistic cities for a protective deity to have a temple or shrine located just outside the city gates.

**"Same nature and vulnerabilities" (v. 15)**: The Greek *homoiopatheis* means "of like passions" or "subject to the same feelings." It is a direct rebuttal to the crowd’s claim that they are "gods in human form." Paul is emphasizing their shared human frailty.

**"Worthless things" (v. 15)**: The Greek *mataiōn* (vanities/empty things) was a standard Jewish rhetorical term for idols (reflecting the Hebrew *hebel*). To the original audience, this was a sharp critique of the local cultic practices as being devoid of reality or power.

**"Crushing pressures" (v. 22)**: The Greek *thlipseōn* is often translated as "tribulations" or "afflictions," but its root meaning refers to pressure, like that used in a wine press. It conveys the intense social and physical weight of persecution described in the preceding verses.

**"Appointed" (v. 23)**: The verb *cheirotonēsantes* originally meant to vote by a show of hands, but by the first century, it had come to mean "to appoint" or "to designate," often by those in authority. 

**"Commended" (v. 26)**: The Greek *paradedomenoi* (from *paradidōmi*) is a formal term meaning "handed over" or "entrusted." The church at Antioch had "entrusted" the apostles to God's care for this specific mission.

verses.text: Now some men came down from Judea and began teaching the brothers, “Unless you are circumcised according to the custom prescribed by Moses, you cannot be saved.”

This led to substantial discord and intense debate between them and Paul and Barnabas. Consequently, it was arranged for Paul, Barnabas, and some others from their group to go up to Jerusalem to see the apostles and elders regarding this dispute.
So, after being sent on their way by the church, they passed through both Phoenicia and Samaria, recounting in detail the conversion of the Gentiles, which brought great joy to all the brothers.
When they arrived in Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church, the apostles, and the elders, and they reported everything God had accomplished through them.
But some believers who belonged to the sect of the Pharisees stood up and said, “It is necessary to circumcise them and to command them to keep the Law of Moses.”
The apostles and the elders gathered to look into this matter.

After much debate, Peter stood up and said to them, “Brothers, you know that in the early days, God made a choice among you that through my mouth the Gentiles should hear the message of the good news and believe.
And God, who knows the secrets of the heart, testified to them by giving them the Holy Spirit just as he did to us.
He made no distinction between us and them, having cleansed their hearts by faith.
Now then, why are you putting God to the test by placing a yoke upon the neck of the disciples—a burden that neither our fathers nor we have been strong enough to bear?
On the contrary, we believe that we are saved through the grace of the Lord Jesus, in the very same way they are.”
The entire assembly fell silent as they listened to Barnabas and Paul describe all the signs and wonders God had performed among the Gentiles through them.
After they finished speaking, James responded, “Brothers, listen to me.
Simeon has described how God first intervened to take from among the nations a people for his name.
The words of the prophets agree with this, as it is written:
‘After these things I will return and rebuild the fallen tent of David; I will rebuild its ruins and restore it,
so that the rest of humanity may seek the Lord—even all the nations over whom my name has been invoked, says the Lord, who does these things
known from ages past.’
Therefore, it is my judgment that we should not place obstacles in the way of those from among the nations who are turning to God.
Instead, we should write to them to abstain from things polluted by idols, from sexual immorality, from what has been strangled, and from blood.
For from ancient generations, Moses has had those who preach him in every city, being read aloud in the synagogues every Sabbath.”

Then it seemed best to the apostles and the elders, together with the whole church, to choose men from among them and send them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas. They chose Judas (called Barsabbas) and Silas, men who were leaders among the brothers.
They sent the following letter with them: “The apostles and the elders, your brothers, to the brothers among the nations in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia: Greetings!
Since we have heard that some of our number have gone out and disturbed you with their talk, unsettling your minds—though we gave them no such instructions—
it seemed best to us, having reached a unanimous decision, to choose men and send them to you along with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,
men who have risked their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
We have therefore sent Judas and Silas, who will themselves report these same things by word of mouth.
For it seemed best to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay no greater burden upon you than these necessary things:
to abstain from meat sacrificed to idols, from blood, from what has been strangled, and from sexual immorality. If you keep yourselves free from these things, you will do well. Farewell.”
So, when the messengers were sent off, they went down to Antioch. They gathered the assembly together and delivered the letter.
When the people read it, they rejoiced at the encouragement.
Judas and Silas, who were themselves prophets, encouraged and strengthened the brothers with a long message.
After spending some time there, they were sent off in peace by the brothers to return to those who had sent them.
But Paul and Barnabas stayed in Antioch, teaching and proclaiming the word of the Lord, along with many others.
After some days, Paul said to Barnabas, “Let’s return and visit the brothers in every city where we proclaimed the word of the Lord, to see how they are doing.”
Barnabas wanted to take John (called Mark) along with them.
But Paul insisted that they should not take along the man who had abandoned them in Pamphylia and had not accompanied them in the work.
A sharp clash of temper resulted, so that they parted ways. Barnabas took Mark and sailed away to Cyprus,
while Paul chose Silas and departed, having been commended by the brothers to the grace of the Lord.
He traveled through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches.

chapters.notes:
**"Custom" (v. 1)**: The Greek *ethos* refers to the prescribed religious practice or the Mosaic "way of life." To a first-century Jew, this wasn't just a "tradition" but the authoritative legal framework of the covenant.

**"Sect" (v. 5)**: The Greek *hairesis* (from which we get "heresy") did not yet carry a purely negative connotation of false teaching. It referred to a "school of thought" or a recognized faction within a larger religion, such as the Pharisees or Sadducees.

**"God, who knows the secrets of the heart" (v. 8)**: The Greek *kardiognostes* is a compound word meaning "heart-knower." This emphasizes God's unique ability to perceive the internal reality of faith in Gentiles, bypassing the external marker of circumcision.

**"Yoke" (v. 10)**: In Jewish thought, the "yoke of the Torah" was a common idiom for taking on the obligation of the Law. Peter uses the term here to argue that the ritual law is an unbearable weight when divorced from the Spirit's power.

**"Intervened" (v. 14)**: The Greek *epeskepsato* (often "visited") carries the nuance of a divine visitation or a providential oversight where God acts on behalf of a people.

**"Tent of David" (v. 16)**: Translating *skene* as "tent" preserves the allusion to the humble, mobile dwelling of David's line (Amos 9:11 LXX) as opposed to a permanent "palace," emphasizing the restoration of the Davidic kingdom through the Messiah.

**"Polluted by idols" (v. 20)**: This refers specifically to meat that had been sacrificed in pagan temples (*eidōlothytōn* in v. 29), which would have been a major source of social and religious defilement for a Jewish-Gentile community.

**"Unsettling your minds" (v. 24)**: The Greek *anaskeuazontes* is a strong term meaning to "dismantle," "pack up," or "subvert." It suggests that the unauthorized teachers were tearing down the spiritual foundation the converts had built.

**"A sharp clash of temper" (v. 39)**: The Greek *paroxysmos* (the root of the English "paroxysm") denotes a sudden, sharp irritation or a provocation. It indicates that the disagreement between Paul and Barnabas was not a mild difference of opinion but an intense emotional conflict.

verses.text: Paul arrived at Derbe and then Lystra, where he found a disciple named Timothy. He was the son of a Jewish woman who was a believer, but his father was a Greek.
The brothers in Lystra and Iconium spoke well of Timothy, giving a strong witness to his character.
Paul wanted this man to travel with him, so he took him and performed the rite of circumcision because of the Jews who lived in those parts; for everyone knew that his father was a Greek.
As they traveled through the cities, they delivered the resolved decisions that had been reached by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem for the people to observe.
So the churches were being solidified in the faith and were growing in number every day.
They traveled through the region of Phrygia and Galatia, having been prevented by the Holy Spirit from speaking the word in the province of Asia.
When they came opposite Mysia, they tried to enter Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus did not permit them.
So, bypassing Mysia, they went down to Troas.
During the night, a vision appeared to Paul: a man from Macedonia was standing there, appealing to him and saying, "Cross over to Macedonia and help us."
As soon as he saw the vision, we immediately sought to depart for Macedonia, concluding that God had called us to announce the good news to them.
Setting sail from Troas, we ran a straight course to Samothrace, and on the following day to Neapolis.
From there we went to Philippi, which is a leading city of the district of Macedonia and a Roman colony. We stayed in this city for several days.
On the Sabbath day, we went outside the city gate to the riverbank, where we expected there to be a place of prayer. We sat down and began speaking to the women who had gathered there.

One of them was a woman named Lydia, a dealer in expensive purple cloth from the city of Thyatira and a worshiper of God. She was listening, and the Lord opened her heart to pay close attention to what Paul was saying.
When she and her household were baptized, she urged us, saying, "If you have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come and stay at my house." And she prevailed upon us.
It happened that as we were going to the place of prayer, we were met by a slave girl who had a spirit of the Python—a spirit of divination. She brought her masters a large profit by fortune-telling.
She followed Paul and the rest of us, shouting out, "These men are slaves of the Most High God, who are proclaiming to you a way of salvation!"
She kept doing this for many days. Paul became deeply annoyed, and turning to the spirit, he said, "I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her!" And it came out that very hour.
When her masters saw that their hope for profit had left them, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them into the marketplace before the authorities.
Bringing them before the chief magistrates, they said, "These men are Jewish, and they are throwing our city into an uproar.
They are advocating customs that are not lawful for us to accept or practice, since we are Romans."
The crowd joined in the attack against them, and the chief magistrates had them stripped of their clothes and ordered them to be beaten with rods.
After they had inflicted many blows on them, they threw them into prison, commanding the jailer to guard them securely.
Having received such a command, he threw them into the inner prison and fastened their feet in the stocks.
About midnight, Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the other prisoners were listening to them.
Suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken. Immediately all the doors flew open and everyone’s chains were unfastened.
When the jailer woke up and saw the prison doors open, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself, assuming the prisoners had escaped.
But Paul cried out in a loud voice, "Do not harm yourself! We are all here!"
The jailer called for lights, rushed in, and fell trembling before Paul and Silas.
He brought them out and asked, "Sirs, what must I do to be saved?"
They said, "Believe in the Lord Jesus, and you will be saved—you and your household."
Then they spoke the word of the Lord to him and to everyone in his house.
At that same hour of the night, he took them and washed their wounds, and he and all his family were baptized at once.
He brought them up into his house and set a meal before them, and he rejoiced greatly with his whole household that he had come to believe in God.
When day broke, the chief magistrates sent their lictors with the order: "Release those men."
The jailer reported these words to Paul, saying, "The magistrates have sent word to release you. So come out now and go in peace."

But Paul said to the lictors, "They beat us publicly without a trial—men who are Roman citizens—and threw us into prison. And now they are going to throw us out secretly? Absolutely not! Let them come themselves and escort us out."
The lictors reported these words to the chief magistrates, who became terrified when they heard they were Roman citizens.
So they came and apologized to them; after escorting them out, they kept requesting that they leave the city.
After leaving the prison, they went to Lydia’s house, and when they saw the brothers, they encouraged them and then departed.

chapters.notes:
**"Resolved decisions" (v. 4)**: The Greek *dogmata* refers to the formal decrees or binding resolutions of the Jerusalem Council (Acts 15). "Decrees" is the traditional rendering, but "resolved decisions" captures the authoritative yet collaborative nature of the early church's discernment.

**"Spirit of the Python" (v. 16)**: The Greek *pneuma pythona* refers to the Python, the serpent or dragon that guarded the Delphic Oracle. In the first century, this was a specific cultural reference to a spirit of divination or "channeling" associated with Apollo. "Divination" alone loses the pagan supernatural color the original audience would have recognized.

**"Chief magistrates" (v. 20)**: The Greek *stratēgoi* corresponds to the Latin *duoviri*, the highest-ranking officials in a Roman colony like Philippi.

**"Customs that are not lawful... since we are Romans" (v. 21)**: This reflects the Roman legal distinction between *religio licita* (authorized religion) and *religio illicita*. The owners are framing the gospel as an illegal foreign cult that threatens Roman social order.

**"Beaten with rods" (v. 22)**: The Greek *rabdizein* refers to the specific Roman punishment of being beaten by the *fasces* (bundles of rods) carried by lictors.

**"Lictors" (v. 35)**: The Greek *rabdouchos* (literally "rod-bearer") refers to the Roman lictors, the attendants who carried out the punishments ordered by the magistrates.

**"Publicly without a trial" (v. 37)**: The Greek *akatakritous* means "uncondemned" or "without due process." Under the *Lex Valeria* and *Lex Porcia*, it was a serious crime to beat a Roman citizen or punish them without a formal trial. Paul is invoking his legal rights to protect the nascent church from being viewed as a group of criminals.

verses.text: After traveling through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue of the Jews.
Following his usual custom, Paul went in to see them, and for three Sabbaths he reasoned with them from the Scriptures.
He opened them up and demonstrated that it was necessary for the Messiah to suffer and to rise from the dead, saying, “This Jesus, whom I am proclaiming to you, is the Messiah.”
Some of them were persuaded and were joined to Paul and Silas, as was a great multitude of the God-fearing Greeks and not a few of the leading women.

But the Jews became jealous. Recruiting some wicked men from the loiterers in the marketplace and forming a mob, they threw the city into an uproar. They descended on Jason’s house, seeking to bring Paul and Silas out to the assembly of the people.
When they did not find them, they dragged Jason and some of the brothers before the politarchs, shouting, “These men who have caused turmoil throughout the whole empire have now come here,
and Jason has welcomed them as guests! They are all acting in defiance of Caesar’s decrees, claiming there is another king—Jesus.”
They agitated the crowd and the politarchs who heard these things.
After they had taken a legal bond from Jason and the others, they released them.
The brothers immediately sent Paul and Silas away to Berea by night. Upon arriving, they went into the synagogue of the Jews.
These people were of more noble character than those in Thessalonica; they received the word with great eagerness, examining the Scriptures every day to see if these things were so.
Consequently, many of them believed, including a significant number of prominent Greek women and men.
But when the Jews from Thessalonica learned that the word of God had been proclaimed by Paul in Berea as well, they came there too, agitating and stirring up the crowds.
The brothers then immediately sent Paul away to the coast, but Silas and Timothy remained there.
Those escorting Paul brought him as far as Athens; and after receiving instructions for Silas and Timothy to join him as soon as possible, they departed.
While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, his spirit was deeply distressed within him as he observed that the city was full of idols.
So he began reasoning in the synagogue with the Jews and the God-fearing Greeks, and in the marketplace every day with those who happened to be there.

Some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also engaged with him. Some said, “What is this intellectual scavenger trying to say?” Others said, “He seems to be a proclaimer of foreign deities,” because he was preaching the good news of Jesus and the Resurrection.
They took hold of him and brought him to the Areopagus, saying, “May we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting?
For you are bringing some startling things to our ears, and we want to know what these things mean.”
(Now all the Athenians and the foreigners residing there spent their time in nothing else but telling or hearing something new.)
Standing in the middle of the Areopagus, Paul said: “Men of Athens, I see that in every way you are very religious.

For as I was passing through and observing the objects of your worship, I even found an altar on which had been inscribed: ‘To an Unknown God.’ Therefore, what you worship in ignorance, this I proclaim to you.
The God who made the world and everything in it, being Lord of heaven and earth, does not dwell in temples made by human hands.
Nor is he served by human hands as though he needed anything, since he himself gives to everyone life and breath and all things.
From one man he made every nation of humanity to inhabit the whole face of the earth, having determined their appointed eras and the boundaries of their dwelling place,
so that they might seek God, if perhaps they might grope for him and find him—though he is actually not far from each one of us.
For ‘in him we live and move and exist,’ as even some of your own poets have said, ‘For we are also his offspring.’
Since we are the offspring of God, we ought not to suppose that the Divine Being is like gold or silver or stone, an image formed by human art and imagination.
Although God overlooked the times of ignorance, he now commands all people everywhere to repent,
because he has set a day on which he is going to judge the inhabited world in righteousness by a man whom he has appointed; and he has provided proof to everyone by raising him from the dead.”
When they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some began to scoff, but others said, “We will hear you again about this.”
So Paul left their assembly.
But some men joined him and believed, among whom were Dionysius the Areopagite, a woman named Damaris, and others with them.

chapters.notes:
**"God-fearing Greeks" (v. 4, 17)**: The term *sebomenōn* refers to a specific class of Gentiles in the first century who were attracted to Jewish monotheism and ethics and attended synagogue, but had not fully converted (i.e., undergone circumcision).

**"Politarchs" (v. 6, 8)**: The Greek *politarchas* is a precise Macedonian title for city officials. For centuries, critics thought Luke was in error because the term didn't appear in classical literature, but archaeology has since found numerous inscriptions using this exact title in Thessalonica.

**"Empire" / "Inhabited world" (v. 6, 31)**: The Greek *oikoumenē* literally means the "inhabited [world]," but in a first-century context, it specifically referred to the Roman Empire and its civilization.

**"Legal bond" (v. 9)**: The phrase *labontes to hikanon* is a Greek translation of the Latin legal term *satisdatio*. It refers to a sum of money deposited as security to guarantee future good behavior or compliance with a judicial order.

**"Noble character" (v. 11)**: *Eugenesteroi* literally means "better born" or "more noble," but here it refers to the character and openness of the Bereans’ minds rather than their social status.

**"Intellectual scavenger" (v. 18)**: The Greek *spermologos* refers to a bird (like a crow) that picks up seeds. In Athenian slang, it was a biting insult for someone who picked up scraps of ideas from various philosophies and parroted them without understanding—an "intellectual magpie."

**"The Resurrection" (v. 18)**: Paul was preaching *Anastasis* (Resurrection). Some scholars suggest the Athenians, accustomed to personified deities, mistakenly thought Paul was introducing a male god (Jesus) and a female goddess (Anastasis).

**"Areopagus" (v. 19, 22)**: This refers both to the location (Mars Hill) and the venerable council of Athens that met there, which had jurisdiction over religious and educational matters.

**"Very religious" (v. 22)**: The word *deisidaimonesterous* is intentionally ambiguous. It can mean "superstitious" (negative) or "devout" (positive). Paul uses a diplomatic term that acknowledges their piety while preparing to critique its direction.

**"The Divine Being" (v. 29)**: The Greek *to theion* is a philosophical term for the nature of God, used here to engage the Stoic and Epicurean listeners on their own linguistic ground.

**"Provided proof" (v. 31)**: The word *pistin* usually means "faith," but in this rhetorical context, it refers to the "ground for belief" or "objective proof" offered by the historical event of the resurrection.

verses.text: After these events, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
There he found a Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, who had recently arrived from Italy with his wife Priscilla because Claudius had ordered all the Jews to depart from Rome. Paul approached them,
and because they shared the same trade, he stayed with them and they worked together; by trade, they were artisans of leather and canvas.
Every Sabbath he would hold discussions in the synagogue, attempting to persuade both Jews and Greeks.
When Silas and Timothy arrived from Macedonia, Paul began to devote himself entirely to the message, solemnly testifying to the Jews that the Christ is Jesus.
But when they resisted and spoke abusively, he shook out his garments and said to them, “Your blood be on your own heads! I am clean of responsibility. From now on, I will go to the nations.”
So he left that place and moved into the house of a man named Titius Justus, a worshiper of God whose house was right next door to the synagogue.
Crispus, the leader of the synagogue, came to believe in the Lord along with his entire household; and many of the Corinthians, as they listened, believed and were baptized.
One night the Lord spoke to Paul through a vision: “Do not be afraid, but keep on speaking and do not be silent,
because I am with you. No one will lay a hand on you to harm you, for I have many people in this city.”
So he settled there for a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them.
But while Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews rose up as one against Paul and brought him before the judgment seat,
saying, “This man is persuading people to worship God in ways that are contrary to the law.”
As Paul was about to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews, “If this were a matter of some injustice or a wicked crime, O Jews, it would be reasonable for me to put up with you.
But if these are questions about a message and names and your own law, see to it yourselves; I do not wish to be a judge of these things.”
And he drove them away from the judgment seat.
Then the whole crowd seized Sosthenes, the leader of the synagogue, and began beating him in front of the judgment seat. But Gallio paid no attention to any of it.

After staying on for a considerable number of days, Paul said goodbye to the brothers and sisters and sailed for Syria, accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila. At Cenchreae he had his hair cut, for he was under a vow.
When they reached Ephesus, he left Priscilla and Aquila there, but he himself entered the synagogue and held discussions with the Jews.
When they asked him to stay for a longer time, he did not consent,
but as he said goodbye he told them, “I will return to you again, God willing.” Then he set sail from Ephesus.
When he landed at Caesarea, he went up and greeted the church, and then went down to Antioch.
After spending some time there, he departed and went from place to place through the region of Galatia and Phrygia, strengthening all the disciples.
Now a Jew named Apollos, a native of Alexandria, arrived in Ephesus. He was an eloquent man, well-versed in the Scriptures.
He had been instructed in the Way of the Lord, and being fervent in spirit, he spoke and taught accurately the facts about Jesus, though he knew only the baptism of John.
He began to speak boldly in the synagogue; but when Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him aside and explained the Way of God to him more accurately.

When he wanted to cross over into Achaia, the brothers and sisters encouraged him and wrote to the disciples there to welcome him. Upon his arrival, he greatly assisted those who had believed through grace,
for he vigorously refuted the Jews in public, demonstrating through the Scriptures that the Christ is Jesus.

chapters.notes:
**"Artisans of leather and canvas" (v. 3)**: The Greek *skēnopoioi* is traditionally rendered "tentmakers." However, in the first-century economy, this trade involved working with leather and heavy woven cloth to create not only tents but also awnings and various travel gear. The broader phrase captures the technical skill involved.

**"Devote himself entirely to the message" (v. 5)**: The Greek *syneicheto tō logō* suggests Paul was "constrained" or "absorbed" by the word. Once his coworkers arrived (likely bringing financial support from Macedonia), he was no longer split between trade-work and preaching, but could focus exclusively on the proclamation.

**"The nations" (v. 6)**: The Greek *ethnē* is often translated "Gentiles," but in a Jewish context (like Paul’s address here), it specifically refers to the non-Jewish nations of the world.

**"Judgment seat" (v. 12, 16, 17)**: The *bēma* was a raised stone platform in the agora (marketplace) where official Roman business was conducted and judicial decisions were rendered.

**"A message and names" (v. 15)**: Gallio uses the term *logos* dismissively. To a Roman magistrate, the fine points of Jewish messianic claims were merely "words" or "talk" (*logos*) and semantic disputes over titles ("names"), rather than matters of civil law.

**"The Way" (v. 25, 26)**: "The Way" (*hē hodos*) was the earliest self-designation for the movement of Jesus’s followers, likely drawing on the "Way of the LORD" in Isaiah and the Psalms.

**"Fervent in spirit" (v. 25)**: The Greek *zeōn* literally means "boiling." It describes an intense, bubbling enthusiasm or spiritual heat.

**"Vigorously" (v. 28)**: The Greek *eutonōs* (from *eu* "well" and *tonos* "tension/tone") suggests a high-energy, muscular style of argumentation—he was "putting his strength" into the debate.

verses.text: It happened that while Apollos was in Corinth, Paul traveled through the inland regions and came down to Ephesus. There he found certain disciples
and asked them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you became believers?” They replied, “No, we have not even heard that there is a Holy Spirit.”
“Into what, then, were you baptized?” Paul asked. “Into John’s baptism,” they said.
Paul explained, “John baptized with a baptism of repentance, telling the people that they must believe in the one coming after him—that is, in Jesus.”
On hearing this, they were baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus.
When Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came upon them, and they began speaking in tongues and prophesying.
There were about twelve men in all.
Paul then entered the synagogue and spoke out boldly for three months, debating and persuading them about the Kingdom of God.

But when some grew stubborn and refused to believe—slandering “The Way” before the whole assembly—he withdrew from them. He took the disciples with him and conducted daily discussions in the lecture hall of Tyrannus.
This continued for two years, so that everyone living in the province of Asia, both Jews and Greeks, heard the message of the Lord.
God was performing extraordinary miracles through Paul’s hands,
so that even sweat-cloths or work-aprons that had touched his skin were carried to the sick; their diseases left them and the evil spirits went out of them.
Then some itinerant Jewish exorcists also attempted to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had evil spirits, saying, “I adjure you by the Jesus whom Paul proclaims!”
Seven sons of a Jewish chief priest named Sceva were doing this.
But the evil spirit answered them, “Jesus I recognize, and Paul I know about, but you—who are you?”
Then the man with the evil spirit leaped on them, mastered them all, and overpowered them, so that they fled out of that house naked and battered.
This became known to everyone living in Ephesus, both Jews and Greeks. Fear fell upon them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was held in high honor.
Many of those who had become believers came forward, openly confessing and disclosing their magical practices.

A large number of those who had practiced the sorcerous arts collected their scrolls and burned them in the sight of everyone. When the value of these was calculated, it totaled fifty thousand silver drachmas.
In this powerful way, the message of the Lord continued to grow and prevail.
After these events, Paul resolved in his spirit to pass through Macedonia and Achaia and then go to Jerusalem. He said, “After I have been there, I must also see Rome.”
So he sent two of his assistants, Timothy and Erastus, into Macedonia, while he himself stayed in the province of Asia for a while longer.
About that time, a major disturbance erupted concerning “The Way.”
A man named Demetrius, a silversmith who made silver models of the shrines of Artemis, provided no small amount of business for the craftsmen.
He gathered these craftsmen together, along with workers in related trades, and said, “Men, you know that our prosperity comes from this business.

And you see and hear that not only in Ephesus but in almost the whole province of Asia, this Paul has persuaded and led away a substantial crowd, saying that gods made by human hands are not gods at all.

There is a danger not only that our trade will fall into disrepute, but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis will be counted as nothing, and she whom all Asia and the whole world worships will be stripped of her majesty.”
When they heard this, they were filled with rage and began shouting, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
The city was filled with confusion. They rushed together into the theater, dragging along Gaius and Aristarchus, Macedonians who were Paul’s travel companions.
Paul wanted to go before the assembly of the people, but the disciples would not let him.
Even some of the Asiarchs—high-ranking provincial officials who were his friends—sent word to him, pleading with him not to venture into the theater.
Now some were shouting one thing and some another, for the assembly was in total chaos, and the majority did not even know why they had come together.
Some of the crowd prompted Alexander, whom the Jews had pushed forward. Alexander motioned with his hand, wanting to make a defense to the people.
But when they recognized that he was a Jew, a single cry rose from them all as they shouted for about two hours, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”

Finally, the town clerk quieted the crowd and said, “Men of Ephesus, is there anyone who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is the temple guardian of the great Artemis and of the image that fell from heaven?
Since these facts are undeniable, you ought to keep calm and do nothing reckless.
For you have brought these men here, though they are neither temple-robbers nor blasphemers of our goddess.
If, therefore, Demetrius and his fellow craftsmen have a grievance against anyone, the courts are open and there are proconsuls; let them bring charges against one another.
But if you are seeking anything beyond that, it must be settled in the legal assembly.
For we are actually in danger of being charged with rioting regarding today’s events, since there is no justification we can give for this disorderly commotion.”
And after saying this, he dismissed the assembly.

chapters.notes:
**"The inland regions" (v. 1)**: The Greek *anōterika merē* (literally "upper parts") refers to the higher-altitude inland route to Ephesus, as opposed to the coastal road.

**"The Way" (v. 9, 23)**: This was the earliest self-designation for the movement of Jesus-followers, likely emphasizing their lifestyle and the "way of salvation." It is capitalized here as a proper title.

**"Lecture hall" (v. 9)**: The Greek *scholē* is the origin of the English word "school," but in the first century, it specifically referred to a place of professional or philosophical lectures.

**"Sweat-cloths or work-aprons" (v. 12)**: *Soudaria* (Latin *sudarium*) were cloths for wiping perspiration (often tied around the head), and *simikinthia* (Latin *semicinctium*) were the linen aprons used by workers or artisans. Using these specific terms highlights Paul's status as a manual laborer (tentmaker).

**"Jesus I recognize, and Paul I know about" (v. 15)**: The Greek uses two different verbs: *ginōskō* (personal, relational knowledge) for Jesus, and *epistamai* (factual acquaintance or being "up on" someone) for Paul. The spirit acknowledges Jesus's authority and Paul's reputation but denies the exorcists any standing.

**"Magical practices / sorcerous arts" (v. 18-19)**: *Praxeis* (v. 18) often refers to "spells" or "magical formulas" in this context. *Ta perierga* (v. 19) literally means "the meddlesome things," a standard technical term for magic in the Greco-Roman world, implying interference in matters that belong to the gods.

**"Asiarchs" (v. 31)**: These were the "leading men of Asia," a specific group of wealthy, influential citizens who held annual religious and civic offices in the province. 

**"Temple guardian" (v. 35)**: The Greek *neōkoron* (literally "temple-sweeper") was a highly coveted title for a city that served as the official custodian of a major deity's temple.

**"The image that fell from heaven" (v. 35)**: *Diopetous* literally means "fallen from Zeus." This likely referred to a meteorite that the Ephesians believed was a divinely crafted statue of Artemis.

**"Legal assembly" (v. 39)**: The *ennomos ekklēsia* was the official, constitutionally sanctioned meeting of the city’s citizens, as opposed to the spontaneous and "illegal" riot (*stasis*) described in v. 40. I have translated *ekklēsia* as "assembly" throughout this section to maintain its civic meaning in a Greek city-state.

verses.text: After the uproar had subsided, Paul sent for the disciples and, after encouraging them, said his farewells and departed to travel into Macedonia.
He passed through those regions, giving the people there much encouragement through his teaching, and eventually arrived in Greece.
He stayed there for three months, but when a plot was formed against him by the Judeans just as he was about to set sail for Syria, he decided to return by way of Macedonia.
He was accompanied by Sopater son of Pyrrhus from Beroea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, Gaius from Derbe, Timothy, and Tychicus and Trophimus from the province of Asia.
These men went on ahead and were waiting for us at Troas.
But we sailed away from Philippi after the Days of Unleavened Bread, and in five days we reached them at Troas, where we stayed for seven days.
On the first day of the week, when we were gathered together to break bread, Paul began a dialogue with them. Since he intended to leave the next day, he extended his discourse until midnight.
Now there were many lamps in the upstairs room where we were gathered.

A certain young man named Eutychus was sitting in the window, and as Paul’s discourse went on and on, he was overcome by a deep sleep. While fast asleep, he fell from the third story down to the ground and was picked up dead.
But Paul went down, threw himself upon him, and took him in his arms, saying, “Do not be alarmed, for his life is in him.”
Then Paul went back upstairs, broke the bread and ate, and after conversing with them for a long time until daybreak, he finally departed.
They took the lad away alive and were comforted beyond measure.
We went on ahead to the ship and set sail for Assos, intending to take Paul aboard there; for he had arranged it this way, intending to travel there himself on foot.
When he met us at Assos, we took him aboard and went to Mitylene.
Sailing from there, we arrived opposite Chios the following day. The day after that, we crossed over to Samos, and on the next day, we came to Miletus.

For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus so that he would not have to spend time in the province of Asia; he was hurrying so that, if it were possible for him, he could be in Jerusalem by the day of Pentecost.
From Miletus, he sent word to Ephesus and summoned the elders of the church.
When they arrived, he said to them: “You yourselves know how I lived among you the entire time from the first day I set foot in Asia,
serving as a slave to the Lord with all humility and with tears and trials that came upon me through the plots of the Judeans.
You know that I did not shrink back from declaring to you anything that was profitable, teaching you both publicly and from house to house,
solemnly testifying to both Jews and Greeks regarding repentance toward God and faith in our Lord Jesus.
“And now, look—compelled by the Spirit, I am on my way to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there,
except that the Holy Spirit solemnly warns me in city after city that imprisonment and afflictions await me.

But I do not consider my life of any account as precious to myself, if only I may finish my course and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus: to solemnly testify to the Good News of the grace of God.
“And now, look—I know that none of you among whom I went about proclaiming the Kingdom will ever see my face again.
Therefore, I testify to you this very day that I am clean of the blood of all men.
For I did not shrink back from declaring to you the whole purpose of God.
Keep watch over yourselves and over all the flock, among whom the Holy Spirit has appointed you as overseers to shepherd the church of God, which he acquired through the blood of his own.
“I know that after my departure savage wolves will come in among you, not sparing the flock.
Even from your own number, men will arise speaking distorted things to draw away the disciples after them.
Therefore, be alert! Remember that for three years, night and day, I never stopped warning each one of you with tears.
“And now I entrust you to God and to the Logos of his grace, which is able to build you up and give you the inheritance among all those who are sanctified.
I coveted no one’s silver or gold or clothing.
You yourselves know that these hands of mine served my own needs and those who were with me.

In everything I have shown you that by laboring in this way, it is necessary to help the weak, remembering the words of the Lord Jesus, for he himself said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”
When he had said these things, he knelt down with them all and prayed.
There was much weeping by everyone as they threw their arms around Paul’s neck and kissed him repeatedly,
grieving most of all over the word he had spoken—that they would never see his face again. Then they escorted him to the ship.

chapters.notes:
**"Break bread" (v. 7)**: The Greek *klasai arton* refers to more than a common meal; in the context of the "first day of the week" (the Christian day of assembly), it carries Eucharistic and communal weight for the early church.

**"Dialogue" / "Discourse" (v. 7, 9)**: The Greek *dielegeto* (from which we get "dialogue") suggests an interactive discussion or reasoning session rather than a modern one-way sermon.

**"Life" (v. 10)**: The Greek *psychē* can mean "soul" or "life." In this context, echoing the miracles of Elijah and Elisha, it refers to the vital life-force returning to or remaining in the young man.

**"Serving as a slave" (v. 19)**: The verb *douleuōn* denotes the service of a *doulos* (slave). Paul is not merely "serving" in a general sense; he is emphasizing his total subjection to the Lord's will.

**"Shrink back" (v. 20, 27)**: The verb *hypostellō* was used of drawing back in fear or furling sails. Paul uses it to emphasize his courage and transparency in his mission.

**"Compelled by the Spirit" (v. 22)**: *Dedemenos tō pneumati* literally means "bound by the spirit." It suggests a divine internal pressure or necessity that Paul feels, overriding his own safety.

**"Clean of the blood of all" (v. 26)**: This is a strong allusion to the "watchman" imagery in Ezekiel 3:18-21 and 33:1-9. If the watchman warns the people, their blood is not on his hands. Paul is asserting he has fulfilled his prophetic duty.

**"Overseers" (v. 28)**: The term *episkopous* refers to those with the responsibility of watching over a community. It is used here interchangeably with the functions of "elders" (*presbyterous*, v. 17) and "shepherding."

**"The blood of his own" (v. 28)**: The Greek *dia tou haimatos tou idiou* is grammatically ambiguous. It could mean "through his own blood" (referring to God's blood, a very rare and startling image) or "through the blood of His own [Son]." Given the context of early Christian liturgical language, "His own" was often used as a term of endearment for a son. The translation preserves the ambiguity while pointing toward the costliness of the acquisition.

**"Logos" (v. 32)**: As noted in the guidelines, *Logos* represents the divine, creative, and sustaining "Word" or "Reason" of God. Entrusting them to the "Logos of His grace" implies both the message of the Gospel and the personified power of God's wisdom.

**"More blessed to give than to receive" (v. 35)**: This is an *agraphon*—a saying of Jesus not recorded in the four Gospels but preserved in the oral tradition of the early church. It reflects the "Aramaic substratum" of Jesus's wisdom teachings.

verses.text: When we had finally torn ourselves away from them and set sail, we ran a straight course and came to Cos, then on the following day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
Finding a ship that was crossing over to Phoenicia, we went aboard and set out to sea.
After sighting Cyprus and leaving it behind on our left, we sailed on toward Syria and put in at Tyre, for the ship was to unload its cargo there.
We sought out the disciples and stayed there for seven days. Through the Spirit, they kept telling Paul not to set foot in Jerusalem.
But when our time there was finished, we left and continued our journey. All of them, including wives and children, escorted us until we were outside the city. We knelt down on the beach and prayed,
said our farewells to one another, and went up into the ship; they, however, returned to their own homes.
Completing the voyage from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais, where we greeted the brothers and sisters and stayed with them for one day.
On the next day we left and came to Caesarea, and entering the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the Seven, we stayed with him.
Now this man had four unmarried daughters who possessed the gift of prophecy.
While we were staying there for several days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.

He came to us, took Paul’s belt, and bound his own feet and hands, saying, “The Holy Spirit says this: ‘The man who owns this belt will be bound this way in Jerusalem by the Jews and handed over into the hands of the Gentiles.’”
When we heard this, both we and the local people pleaded with him not to go up to Jerusalem.
Then Paul answered, “What are you doing, weeping and crushing my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound, but even to die in Jerusalem for the sake of the name of the Lord Jesus.”
Since he would not be persuaded, we fell silent, saying only, “The Lord’s will be done.”
After these days, we packed our gear and began the ascent to Jerusalem.
Some of the disciples from Caesarea also went with us, bringing us to the house of Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we were to stay.
When we arrived in Jerusalem, the brothers and sisters welcomed us gladly.
On the following day, Paul went in with us to see James, and all the elders were present.
After greeting them, he related one by one the things God had done among the nations through his ministry.
When they heard it, they glorified God and said to him, “You see, brother, how many tens of thousands there are among the Jews who have believed, and they are all zealots for the Law.

They have been informed about you—that you are teaching all the Jews living among the nations to commit apostasy against Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children or to walk according to our ancestral customs.
What, then, is to be done? They will certainly hear that you have come.
Therefore, do what we tell you: We have four men here who have taken a vow.

Take them, purify yourself along with them, and pay their expenses so that they can have their heads shaved. Then everyone will know that there is no truth in the reports they heard about you, but that you yourself live in conformity with the Law.

But concerning the Gentiles who have believed, we have sent a letter with our judgment: that they should guard themselves against what has been sacrificed to idols, from blood, from what has been strangled, and from sexual immorality.”

Then Paul took the men, and the next day, after purifying himself along with them, he entered the temple to announce when the days of purification would be completed and the offering presented for each one of them.
When the seven days were almost over, the Jews from the province of Asia saw him in the temple. They stirred up the whole crowd and seized him,

shouting, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man who teaches everyone everywhere against our people, our Law, and this place! What is more, he has even brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place!”
(For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him and assumed that Paul had brought him into the temple.)
The whole city was provoked, and the people came running together. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple, and immediately the doors were shut.
While they were trying to kill him, a report went up to the commander of the Roman cohort that all Jerusalem was in a state of chaos.
He immediately took soldiers and centurions and ran down to the crowd. When they saw the commander and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
Then the commander came up, arrested him, and ordered him to be bound with two chains. He began inquiring who he was and what he had done.
Some in the crowd were shouting one thing and some another; since the commander could not get the facts straight because of the uproar, he ordered him to be brought into the barracks.
When Paul reached the steps, he actually had to be carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the mob,
for the mass of people kept following and screaming, “Away with him!”
Just as he was about to be led into the barracks, Paul said to the commander, “Is it permitted for me to say something to you?” He replied, “Do you know Greek?
Then you aren't the Egyptian who some time ago started a rebellion and led four thousand men of the Dagger-Men out into the wilderness?”
Paul answered, “I am a Jew, a Tarsian from Cilicia, a citizen of no obscure city. I beg you, allow me to speak to the people.”
When he had given permission, Paul stood on the steps and motioned with his hand to the people. When a great silence had fallen, he addressed them in the Aramaic dialect:

chapters.notes:
**"Torn ourselves away" (v. 1)**: The Greek *apospasthentas* is a strong term (from *apospao*) suggesting a forceful or painful separation, rather than a casual departure. It conveys the emotional weight of Paul’s final goodbye to the Ephesian elders in the previous chapter.

**"Unmarried daughters" (v. 9)**: While traditionally rendered "virgins," the focus in this context—given the mention of their father’s house and their prophetic role—is likely their status as unmarried women dedicated to the community’s ministry.

**"Crushing my heart" (v. 13)**: The Greek *synthryptontes* means to break into pieces or crush. "Breaking my heart" is the common English idiom, but "crushing" captures the intensity of the verb more accurately.

**"Tens of thousands" (v. 20)**: The Greek *myriades* refers specifically to groups of ten thousand. Using "thousands" (as many translations do) significantly understates the scale of the Jewish Christian movement in Jerusalem described by James.

**"Apostasy" (v. 21)**: The Greek *apostasian* is a technical religious term for a total desertion or rebellion. The rumors weren't just that Paul was being flexible, but that he was actively teaching Jews to "revolt" against the Mosaic covenant.

**"Commander" (v. 31)**: The Greek *chiliarchos* literally means "leader of a thousand." In the Roman military context, this was a Military Tribune.

**"Dagger-Men" (v. 38)**: The Greek *sikariōn* refers to the *Sicarii*, a radical faction of Jewish zealots known for carrying concealed daggers (*sicae*) to assassinate Roman collaborators in crowds. Using "assassins" (traditional) loses the specific historical and political identity of this group.

**"Aramaic dialect" (v. 40)**: The Greek *Hebraïdi dialektō* literally means "Hebrew dialect," but in the first century, this almost certainly referred to Aramaic, the common tongue of Palestinian Jews, rather than biblical Hebrew. Addressing the mob in their native tongue was a strategic move to gain their attention and respect.

verses.text: "Brothers and fathers, listen now to the defense I present to you."
When they heard him addressing them in the Hebrew language, they became even more quiet. Then he said:

"I am a Jewish man, born in Tarsus of Cilicia, but brought up in this very city. At the feet of Gamaliel, I was educated with strict precision in our ancestral law, being a zealot for God just as all of you are today.
I persecuted this Way to the point of death, binding both men and women and handing them over to prisons,

as the high priest and the whole council of elders can testify for me. I even received letters from them to the brothers in Damascus, and I was traveling there to bring those who were there back to Jerusalem in chains so they could be punished.
"As I was on my journey and approaching Damascus about noon, suddenly a blinding radiance of light from heaven flashed all around me.
I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?'
I answered, 'Who are you, Lord?' and he said to me, 'I am Jesus the Nazarene, whom you are persecuting.'
Now those who were with me saw the light, but they did not understand the voice of the one speaking to me.
I said, 'What should I do, Lord?' The Lord said to me, 'Get up and go into Damascus, and there you will be told about everything you have been assigned to do.'
Because I could not see due to the intensity of that light’s glory, I was led by the hand by my companions and entered Damascus.
"A certain Ananias, a man who was devout according to the law and well-regarded by all the Jews living there,
came to me, stood by me, and said, 'Brother Saul, recover your sight!' And at that very moment, I looked up and saw him.
Then he said, 'The God of our fathers has appointed you to know his will, to see the Righteous One, and to hear a voice from his own mouth,
because you will be a witness for him to all people of what you have seen and heard.
And now, why do you delay? Get up, be baptized, and wash away your sins, calling upon his name.'
"After I had returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance
and saw him saying to me, 'Hurry! Get out of Jerusalem quickly, because they will not accept your testimony about me.'
And I said, 'Lord, they themselves know that in synagogue after synagogue I was the one imprisoning and beating those who believe in you.
And when the blood of Stephen, your witness, was being shed, I myself was standing there approving and guarding the cloaks of those who were killing him.'
But he said to me, 'Go, for I will send you far away to the Gentiles.'"
They listened to him up to this point, but then they raised their voices, shouting, "Rid the earth of such a man! He is not fit to live!"
As they were screaming, tossing off their cloaks, and throwing dust into the air,
the tribune ordered him to be brought into the barracks. He directed that Paul be examined under the lash so he could find out the reason they were shouting against him like this.
But as they stretched him out with leather straps, Paul said to the centurion standing there, "Is it legal for you to scourge a man who is a Roman citizen and uncondemned?"
When the centurion heard this, he went to the tribune and reported it, saying, "What are you about to do? This man is a Roman citizen."
So the tribune went and asked him, "Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?" He said, "Yes."
The tribune responded, "I purchased this citizenship for a very large sum of money." Paul said, "But I was actually born a citizen."
Immediately, those who were about to examine him backed away. Even the tribune was alarmed, realizing that he had bound a Roman citizen.

The next day, wanting to know the exact reason why Paul was being accused by the Jews, the tribune released him and ordered the chief priests and the entire Sanhedrin to assemble. He then brought Paul down and had him stand before them.

chapters.notes:
**"The Hebrew language" (v. 2)**: The Greek *tē Hebraïdi dialektō* likely refers to Aramaic, the Semitic vernacular of first-century Judean Jews, rather than biblical Hebrew. However, the author emphasizes "Hebrew" to highlight Paul’s cultural and ethnic identification with his audience, a key theme in his defense.

**"Zealot" (v. 3)**: The Greek *zēlōtēs* carries more weight than the modern "zealous." In this context, it evokes the tradition of Phinehas and Elijah—a fierce, even violent, devotion to the purity of the Law and the honor of God.

**"This Way" (v. 4)**: "The Way" (*hē hodos*) was the earliest self-designation of the Jesus movement, likely drawing on Isaiah’s "Way of the LORD." Capitalizing it identifies it as a specific movement.

**"The intensity of that light’s glory" (v. 11)**: The Greek *doxa* (glory) here refers to the physical weight and blinding brilliance of the divine radiance.

**"The Righteous One" (v. 14)**: *Ton dikaion* is used here as a specific Messianic title, emphasizing Jesus's innocence and his status as the promised servant of God (cf. Isaiah 53:11).

**"Witness" (v. 20)**: The Greek *martys* primarily means "witness" in a legal or testimonial sense. While it is the root of the English "martyr," the transition to that specific meaning (one who dies for their faith) was only just beginning. Stephen is a "witness" whose testimony cost him his life.

**"Tribune" (v. 24)**: A *chiliarchos* was a Roman military commander in charge of a cohort (roughly 1,000 men).

**"Uncondemned" (v. 25)**: The Greek *akatakriton* is a technical legal term. Under the *Lex Valeria* and *Lex Porcia*, it was strictly illegal to scourge a Roman citizen, especially without a formal trial and conviction.

**"Citizenship" (v. 28)**: The Greek *politeia* refers to the rights and status of a citizen. The tribune’s comment about the "large sum" reflects the historical practice under the Emperor Claudius, where Roman citizenship was frequently sold by corrupt officials. Paul’s claim to be "born a citizen" indicates his family had held this status for at least a generation, placing him in a higher social strata than the tribune.

verses.text: Paul fixed his gaze on the Council and said, “Brothers, I have conducted my life as a citizen before God in all good conscience to this very day.”
At this, the high priest Ananias ordered those standing near Paul to strike him on the mouth.
Then Paul said to him, “God is about to strike you, you whitewashed wall! Do you sit there judging me according to the Law, yet in violation of the Law you order me to be struck?”
Those standing by said, “Do you dare to insult God’s high priest?”
Paul replied, “I did not know, brothers, that he was the high priest; for it is written: *You shall not speak evil of a ruler of your people.*”

Realizing that one part of the Council were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, Paul shouted out in the Council chamber, “Brothers, I am a Pharisee, a son of Pharisees! It is concerning the hope of the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial!”
When he said this, a dissension broke out between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was split.
For the Sadducees say there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit, but the Pharisees acknowledge them all.
A great clamor arose, and some of the scribes from the party of the Pharisees stood up and argued heatedly, “We find nothing wrong with this man! What if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him?”
As the dissension became violent, the commander, fearing that Paul would be torn to pieces by them, ordered the troops to go down, take him by force from their midst, and bring him into the barracks.
That following night, the Lord stood by Paul and said, “Take courage! For just as you have solemnly testified about me in Jerusalem, so you must also bear witness in Rome.”
When day broke, a group of Jews formed a conspiracy and bound themselves under a curse, swearing that they would neither eat nor drink until they had killed Paul.
There were more than forty who had joined this conspiracy.
They went to the chief priests and the elders and said, “We have bound ourselves under a solemn curse to taste nothing until we have killed Paul.

Now then, you and the Council should notify the commander to bring him down to you, as though you intend to determine his case more accurately. We are ready to do away with him before he even gets close.”
But the son of Paul’s sister heard about the ambush. He went to the barracks, entered, and reported it to Paul.
Paul called one of the centurions and said, “Take this young man to the commander, for he has something to report to him.”
So the centurion took him and brought him to the commander, saying, “The prisoner Paul called me and asked me to bring this young man to you, as he has something to tell you.”
The commander took him by the hand, withdrew with him privately, and asked, “What is it that you have to report to me?”
He said, “The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the Council tomorrow, as though they were going to inquire more accurately about him.

Do not let them persuade you, for more than forty of them are lying in wait for him. They have bound themselves under a curse neither to eat nor drink until they have done away with him. They are ready even now, just waiting for your consent.”
The commander dismissed the young man, instructing him, “Do not tell anyone that you have disclosed this to me.”
Then he called two of the centurions and said, “Get two hundred soldiers ready to march to Caesarea by nine tonight, along with seventy horsemen and two hundred spearmen.
Provide mounts for Paul to ride so that he may be brought safely to Felix the Governor.”
He wrote a letter to this effect:
“Claudius Lysias, to His Excellency, Governor Felix: Greetings.
This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them when I arrived with the troops and rescued him, having learned that he is a Roman citizen.
Wanting to know the exact charge they were bringing against him, I brought him down to their Council.
I found that he was being accused concerning questions of their own law, but there was no charge against him deserving death or imprisonment.
When it was reported to me that there would be a plot against the man, I sent him to you at once, also ordering his accusers to state their case against him before you.”
So the soldiers, according to their orders, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris.
The next day, they let the horsemen ride on with him while they returned to the barracks.
