When the horsemen arrived in Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they also presented Paul to him.
After reading the letter, the governor asked what province he was from. Learning that he was from Cilicia,
he said, “I will give you a full hearing when your accusers also arrive.” He then ordered that Paul be kept under guard in Herod’s palace.

chapters.notes:
**"Conducted my life as a citizen" (v. 1)**: The Greek verb *πεπολίτευμαι* (from *politeuomai*) relates to one's conduct as a citizen (*polites*) or fulfilling public/civic duties. Paul is not just saying he "lived," but that he fulfilled his obligations toward God’s "commonwealth" or "polity."

**"Whitewashed wall" (v. 3)**: This is a metaphor for hypocrisy, likely alluding to Ezekiel 13:10–15. A wall that is structurally unsound but covered in white plaster looks stable and pure but is ready to collapse. It carries a heavy irony in a trial concerning the "Law."

**"Acknowledge them all" (v. 8)**: The Greek *τὰ ἀμφότερα* literally means "both," yet three things are listed: resurrection, angels, and spirits. In Koine Greek, "both" can group items into two categories. Here, the two categories are likely (1) the resurrection of the body and (2) the existence of spiritual beings (whether angels or spirits).

**"Commander" (v. 10, 15, etc.)**: The Greek *χιλίαρχος* (chiliarch) refers to a Roman military tribune, the commander of a cohort (roughly 1,000 men). "Commander" captures his authority over the "barracks" (the Fortress of Antonia) better than the more obscure "tribune."

**"Bound themselves under a curse" (v. 12, 14, 21)**: The Greek *ἀνεθεμάτισαν* refers to the *anathema*—placing oneself under a divine ban of destruction. They were literally asking God to destroy them if they did not kill Paul.

**"Spearmen" (v. 23)**: The Greek *δεξιολάβους* is a rare term whose precise meaning is debated. It literally means "right-hand takers." While it may refer to light infantry or bodyguards, "spearmen" is the consensus understanding for this type of auxiliary support unit.

**"Nine tonight" (v. 23)**: The Greek is "the third hour of the night." Since the Jewish/Roman night began at 6:00 PM, the third hour is 9:00 PM.

**"Having learned that he is a Roman citizen" (v. 27)**: In the Greek text, Lysias positions the rescue *after* his discovery of Paul's citizenship to make himself look better to the Governor. In reality (as recorded in chapter 22), he discovered the citizenship only after he had already arrested and nearly flogged Paul. The translation preserves this subtle "official spin."

**"Herod's palace" (v. 35)**: The Greek *πραιτωρίῳ* (Praetorium) refers to the governor’s official residence. Since Felix used the palace originally built by Herod the Great in Caesarea as his headquarters, "Herod's palace" is the most contextually descriptive rendering.

verses.text: Five days later, the high priest Ananias arrived with several elders and a professional legal advocate named Tertullus. They presented their formal case against Paul to the governor.
When Paul was summoned, Tertullus began the prosecution, saying: “Because of you, we enjoy a deep peace, and reforms are being brought to this nation through your foresight.
At all times and in all places, most excellent Felix, we receive this with profound gratitude.
But so as not to impose on your time further, I beg you in your characteristic fairness to hear us briefly.
“For we have found this man to be a plague—a source of insurrection among all the Jews throughout the civilized world and a ringleader of the Nazarene sect.
He even attempted to desecrate the Temple, so we seized him.
By examining him yourself, you will be able to confirm all these charges we are bringing against him.”
The Jews also joined in the attack, asserting that these things were so.
When the governor signaled for him to speak, Paul replied: “Since I know you have been a judge over this nation for many years, I confidently offer my defense.
You can easily verify that it has not been more than twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem to worship.
They did not find me debating with anyone in the Temple or inciting a mob—neither in the synagogues nor throughout the city.
Nor can they provide evidence to you for the charges they are now bringing against me.
“However, I do confess this to you: according to The Way (which they call a sect), I worship the God of our ancestors. I believe everything written in the Law and the Prophets,
and I have the same hope in God that these men themselves entertain—that there is going to be a resurrection of both the righteous and the unrighteous.
For this reason, I myself strive always to maintain a clear conscience before God and all people.
“After several years, I arrived to bring charitable gifts to my nation and to present offerings.
While I was doing this, they found me ritually purified in the Temple, without a crowd and without an uproar.
But there were some Jews from the province of Asia—they ought to be here before you to bring charges if they have anything against me.
Or let these men here say what crime they found when I stood before the Council,
other than this one cry I shouted while standing among them: ‘It is concerning the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial before you today!’”
Felix, however, adjourned the proceedings. Having a more accurate knowledge of The Way, he said, “When Lysias the commander comes down, I will decide your case.”
He ordered the centurion to keep Paul in custody but to allow him some liberty and not to prevent any of his own people from attending to his needs.
After some days, Felix arrived with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish. He sent for Paul and listened to him speak about faith in Christ Jesus.
But as Paul discussed righteousness, self-mastery, and the coming judgment, Felix became terrified and replied, “For now, you may go. When I find a convenient time, I will summon you again.”
At the same time, he was hoping that Paul would give him a bribe; for this reason, he used to send for him quite often to converse with him.
When two years had passed, Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus. Since Felix wanted to grant the Jews a favor, he left Paul in prison.

chapters.notes:
**“Legal advocate” (v. 1)**: The Greek *rhētōr* refers to a professional orator or lawyer. In this Roman provincial context, Tertullus is acting as a prosecutor trained in Roman forensic rhetoric.

**“Foresight” (v. 2)**: The Greek *pronoia* (providence/foresight) was a term of high praise in the Greco-Roman world, often attributed to deities or exceptionally wise rulers. Tertullus is using standard high-flattery (*captatio benevolentiae*) to win the governor’s favor.

**“Plague” (v. 5)**: The Greek *loimos* literally means "pestilence." Tertullus is not just calling Paul a "troublemaker"; he is describing him as a contagious disease that threatens the health of the Roman social order.

**“Civilized world” (v. 5)**: *Oikoumenē* refers to the inhabited or Greco-Roman world. To a Roman official, this specifically meant the Empire.

**“Sect” (v. 5, 14)**: The Greek *haeresis* (from which we get "heresy") simply meant a school of thought or a faction (like the Pharisees or Sadducees). In a legal context, it implies a group that has broken away from the mainstream. Paul’s response in v. 14 indicates he views "The Way" not as a breakaway faction, but as the true fulfillment of ancestral Judaism.

**“Textual Note” (vv. 6–8)**: Most modern critical texts (SBLGNT/NA28) omit the end of verse 6, all of verse 7, and the beginning of verse 8 (which involve Lysias taking Paul away with "great violence"). These are absent from the earliest and best manuscripts.

**“Self-mastery” (v. 25)**: *Enkrateia* (often "self-control") was a cardinal virtue in Greek ethics, referring to the power one has over one's own desires and impulses. This would have been a pointed topic to discuss with Felix, who was known for his illicit marriage to Drusilla and his general reputation for cruelty and lust.

**“Bribe” (v. 26)**: The Greek *chrēmata* (money/wealth) in this context refers to a payoff. Roman law (the *Lex Julia de Repetundis*) strictly forbade governors from taking bribes, making Felix's hope particularly corrupt.

**“Grant the Jews a favor” (v. 27)**: The Greek phrase *charita katathesthai* is an idiom for "storing up a favor" or "placing someone in one's debt." Felix leaves Paul imprisoned as a political deposit to mitigate Jewish resentment toward his administration.

verses.text: Three days after Festus had arrived in the province to assume his command, he went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem.
There, the chief priests and the leading men of the Jews officially laid their case against Paul before him. They began appealing to him,
asking as a favor—at Paul’s expense—that Festus would have him transferred to Jerusalem. All the while, they were preparing an ambush to murder him along the road.
Festus replied that Paul was being kept under guard in Caesarea, and that he himself intended to return there shortly.
“Therefore,” he said, “let the authorities among you go down with me, and if there is anything out of order with the man, let them bring their formal charges against him.”
After staying among them no more than eight or ten days, he went down to Caesarea. The next day, he took his seat on the tribunal and ordered Paul to be brought in.
When Paul arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him, bringing many serious charges that they were unable to prove.
Paul said in his own defense, “I have committed no offense against the law of the Jews, or against the temple, or against Caesar.”
But Festus, wishing to curry favor with the Jews, answered Paul: “Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem to be tried there before me on these charges?”
Paul replied, “I am standing before Caesar’s tribunal; this is where I must be tried. I have done no wrong to the Jews, as you yourself know very well.

If, then, I am a lawbreaker and have done anything deserving of death, I do not fix my mind on escaping it. But if there is nothing to the things they accuse me of, no one can hand me over to them as a political favor. I appeal to Caesar!”
Then Festus, after conferring with his council, replied, “You have appealed to Caesar; to Caesar you shall go.”
After several days had passed, King Agrippa and Bernice arrived in Caesarea to pay their respects to Festus.
Since they were staying there for a number of days, Festus laid Paul’s case before the king, saying, “There is a man here whom Felix left behind as a prisoner.
When I was in Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews officially informed me about him, demanding a sentence of condemnation against him.
I answered them that it is not the Roman custom to hand over any person as a favor before the accused meets the accusers face to face and receives an opportunity to defend himself against the charge.
So when they gathered here, I did not delay; the next day I took my seat on the tribunal and ordered the man to be brought in.
When the accusers stood up, they did not bring any of the charges of wrongdoing that I was expecting.
Instead, they had certain points of dispute with him regarding their own religion and regarding a certain Jesus, who is dead, but whom Paul claimed was alive.
Since I was at a loss as to how to investigate such matters, I asked if he was willing to go to Jerusalem to be tried there concerning these things.
But when Paul appealed to be kept in custody for the decision of His Imperial Majesty, I ordered him to be held until I could send him to Caesar.”
Agrippa said to Festus, “I have been wanting to hear the man myself.” “Tomorrow,” Festus said, “you shall hear him.”

So the next day, Agrippa and Bernice came with great pageantry and entered the audience hall together with the military commanders and the prominent men of the city. At the command of Festus, Paul was brought in.

Then Festus said, “King Agrippa and all you men present with us, you see this man about whom the entire Jewish community petitioned me, both in Jerusalem and here, shouting that he ought not to live any longer.
But I found that he had done nothing deserving of death; and since he himself appealed to His Imperial Majesty, I decided to send him.

However, I have nothing definite to write to my lord the Emperor about him. Therefore, I have brought him before all of you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that after this preliminary hearing has taken place, I might have something to write.
For it seems absurd to me to send a prisoner without also specifying the charges against him.”

chapters.notes:
**"Assume his command" (v. 1)**: The Greek *eparcheia* refers to the province or the jurisdiction of a governor. In this context, it marks the formal beginning of Festus’s administration.

**"Officially laid their case" (v. 2, 15)**: The verb *enephanisan* is a technical legal term in Koine Greek, used for making a formal report or presenting a complaint before a magistrate.

**"As a favor—at Paul's expense" (v. 3)**: The Greek *aitoumenoi charin kat’ autou* literally means "asking for a favor against him." The translation reflects the corrupt nature of the request: they are asking the judge for a "gift" (the prisoner’s transfer/death) which violates legal impartiality.

**"Authorities" (v. 5)**: *Dynatoi* refers not just to "powerful people" but specifically to those with the official standing or capacity to act as prosecutors in a legal setting.

**"Tribunal" (v. 6, 10, 17)**: The *bēma* was the raised platform or judicial bench where a Roman magistrate sat to render official decisions.

**"Curry favor" (v. 9)**: The phrase *charin katathesthai* (literally "to lay down a favor") is an idiom for doing someone a service in order to place them in one's debt, often for political leverage.

**"Hand me over... as a political favor" (v. 11, 16)**: The verb *charisasthai* is the verbal form of *charis* (favor/grace). Paul is pointedly calling out Festus for attempting to use a human life as a "gift" to appease a local constituency.

**"Religion" (v. 19)**: *Deisidaimonias* can mean "superstition" (pejorative) or "religion" (neutral). Given that Festus is speaking to King Agrippa, who was Jewish, he likely chose a term that could be interpreted with diplomatic ambiguity, though his own Roman perspective probably leaned toward "superstition."

**"His Imperial Majesty" (v. 21, 25)**: The Greek *Sebastos* is the equivalent of the Latin *Augustus*. At this time, it was a title for Nero.

**"Pageantry" (v. 23)**: *Phantasia* refers to an extravagant outward show or pompous display. This contrasts the worldly splendor of the Roman and Herodian officials with the captive Paul.

**"My lord the Emperor" (v. 26)**: The Greek *kyrios* ("lord") was increasingly used as a divine and imperial title. Festus uses it here in its formal capacity for the Emperor (Nero).

**"Preliminary hearing" (v. 26)**: *Anakrisis* refers specifically to a pre-trial examination used to gather evidence or clarify charges before a case was sent to a higher court.

verses.text: Agrippa said to Paul, “You have permission to speak on your own behalf.” Then Paul, extending his hand in a formal gesture, began his legal defense:
“Regarding all the accusations brought against me by the Judeans, King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate that it is before you I am to make my defense today,
especially since you are an expert in all the customs and controversies of the Jewish people. Therefore, I beg you to listen to me with patience.
All the Judeans know my way of life from my youth, which was spent from the beginning among my own nation and in Jerusalem.
They have known me for a long time, and if they were willing to testify, they could say that I lived as a Pharisee according to the strictest sect of our religion.
And now I stand on trial because of the hope in the promise made by God to our fathers,
a promise which our twelve-tribe nation hopes to attain as they earnestly worship night and day. It is concerning this hope, O King, that I am being accused by Judeans.
Why is it judged unbelievable among you if God raises the dead?
I myself once thought it was necessary to do many things in opposition to the name of Jesus the Nazarene.

This is exactly what I did in Jerusalem; not only did I lock up many of the holy ones in prisons by the authority I received from the chief priests, but when they were being executed, I cast my vote against them.
Throughout all the synagogues, I often punished them to try to force them to revile the Name, and in my raging fury against them, I even pursued them to foreign cities.
While traveling to Damascus on such a mission with the authority and commission of the chief priests,
at midday along the road, O King, I saw a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, shining around me and those traveling with me.
When we had all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me in the Hebrew dialect: ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against the sharp goads.’
I said, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ and the Lord said, ‘I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.

But get up and stand on your feet; for I have appeared to you for this purpose: to appoint you as an assistant and a witness both of the things in which you have seen me and of the things in which I will appear to you.
I am rescuing you from your own people and from the nations—to whom I am sending you

to open their eyes, so that they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and a share of the inheritance among those who have been sanctified by faith in me.’
From that point on, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,

but I began proclaiming, first to those in Damascus and in Jerusalem, then throughout the whole region of Judea and to the nations, that they must repent and turn to God, performing deeds consistent with repentance.
For these reasons, the Judeans seized me in the temple and tried to kill me with their own hands.
Having obtained the help that comes from God to this very day, I stand and witness to both small and great, saying nothing beyond what the Prophets and Moses said would happen:
that the Messiah must suffer, and that as the first to rise from the dead, he would proclaim light both to our people and to the nations.”
As he was saying these things in his defense, Festus shouted out, “You are out of your mind, Paul! Your great learning is driving you into a mania!”
But Paul said, “I am not out of my mind, most excellent Festus, but I am speaking words of truth and of a sound mind.
For the king knows about these things, and I speak freely to him. I am persuaded that none of these things has escaped his notice, for this has not been done in a corner.
King Agrippa, do you believe the Prophets? I know that you believe.”
Agrippa said to Paul, “In such a short time, are you persuading me to act the Christian?”
Paul replied, “Whether in a short time or a long one, I would pray to God that not only you but also all who are listening to me today might become exactly what I am—except for these chains.”
Then the king stood up, along with the governor and Bernice and those sitting with them.
When they had withdrawn, they talked to one another, saying, “This man is doing nothing deserving of death or imprisonment.”
Agrippa said to Festus, “This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.”

chapters.notes:
**"Expert" (v. 3)**: The Greek *gnōstēn* implies someone who is an "authorized knower" or an initiate into the specifics of a subject. Agrippa, being a Herod, was culturally Jewish and familiar with the sectarian nuances in a way Roman governors like Festus were not.

**"Sect" (v. 5)**: The term *hairesis* in the first century referred to a school of thought or a specific party (like the schools of philosophy). It does not yet carry the late-antique or medieval weight of "heresy" as a departure from an established orthodoxy.

**"Twelve-tribe nation" (v. 7)**: The Greek *dōdekaphylon* is a rare collective noun. It emphasizes the theological unity of Israel, despite the historical "lost" tribes, as a single entity waiting for the fulfillment of the promise.

**"Cast my vote" (v. 10)**: The Greek *psēphon* refers to the pebble used in voting. This suggests that Paul may have had a formal judicial role, perhaps as a member of the Sanhedrin or a similar body, rather than just being a vigilante.

**"Hebrew dialect" (v. 14)**: *tē Hebraïdi dialektō* likely refers to Aramaic, the common tongue of Palestinian Jews, though it could refer to the Hebrew language itself. The distinction marks the intimacy and specific cultural targeting of the divine call.

**"Kick against the goads" (v. 14)**: This is a Greek proverb (found in Aeschylus and Euripides). A "goad" was a sharpened stick used to drive oxen. If the ox kicked back against the goad, it only hurt itself more. It describes the futility of resisting a divine or inevitable will.

**"Assistant" (v. 16)**: *hypēretēn* literally means an "under-rower" on a ship, signifying someone who works under the direction of another.

**"Share of the inheritance" (v. 18)**: *klēron* refers to a lot or a portion assigned by divine will, evoking the division of the Promised Land among the tribes of Israel.

**"Kill me with their own hands" (v. 21)**: The verb *diacheirisastai* is a more violent and visceral term than "to kill." It implies a hands-on, manual slaying, fitting for the mob violence Paul faced in the temple.

**"Sound mind" (v. 25)**: *sōphrosynēs* is the direct opposite of *mania*. It refers to self-control, rationality, and clarity of thought—hallmarks of Greek philosophical virtue.

**"In a short time" (v. 28)**: The phrase *en oligō* is notoriously difficult. It can mean "with few words," "in a short time," or "by a small margin." Given Paul's response contrasting it with *en megalō* ("in a great/long [time/margin]"), it likely refers to the speed or ease of the conversion process. Agrippa’s tone is likely ironic or deflective.

**"To act the Christian" (v. 28)**: The Greek *Christianon poiēsai* (literally "to make/do a Christian") suggests Agrippa is commenting on Paul’s attempt to push him into a role or a identity, rather than a deep internal change. "Christian" was still likely a derogatory or external label at this time.

verses.text: When it was decided that we should sail for Italy, they handed Paul and some other prisoners over to a centurion named Julius, of the Augustan Cohort.
We boarded a ship from Adramyttium that was about to sail to the ports along the coast of Asia and put out to sea. Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, was with us.
The next day we put in at Sidon. Julius treated Paul with great consideration, allowing him to go to his friends to receive their care.
Putting out to sea from there, we sailed under the lee of Cyprus because the winds were against us.
After we had sailed across the open sea off Cilicia and Pamphylia, we reached Myra in Lycia.
There the centurion found an Alexandrian ship sailing for Italy and put us on board.
For many days we sailed slowly and arrived with difficulty off Cnidus. Since the wind did not allow us to go further, we sailed under the lee of Crete off Salmone.
Coasting along it with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near the city of Lasea.
Much time had been lost, and sailing was now dangerous because even the Fast had already passed. So Paul began to warn them,
saying, “Men, I can see that this voyage is going to involve disaster and great loss, not only of the cargo and the ship, but also of our lives.”
But the centurion was more persuaded by the pilot and the ship-owner than by what Paul said.

Since the harbor was unsuitable for wintering, the majority reached a decision to put out to sea from there, hoping somehow to reach Phoenix, a harbor in Crete facing both southwest and northwest, and to winter there.
When a moderate south wind began to blow, they thought they had achieved their purpose; they weighed anchor and began to sail close along the shore of Crete.
But before long, a hurricane-force wind, the one called a “Northeaster,” rushed down from the island.
The ship was caught by it and could not head into the wind, so we gave way to it and were driven along.
Running under the lee of a small island called Cauda, we were barely able to secure the ship’s boat.
After hoisting it up, they used support cables to undergird the ship. Fearing they might run aground on the Syrtis sands, they lowered the sea-anchor and so were driven along.
Because we were being violently tossed by the storm, the next day they began to throw the cargo overboard.
On the third day, they threw the ship’s gear overboard with their own hands.
When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and the great storm continued to batter us, all hope of our being saved was finally abandoned.

Since they had gone without food for a long time, Paul stood up among them and said, “Men, you should have followed my advice not to put out to sea from Crete and so have avoided this disaster and loss.
But now I urge you to take heart, for there will be no loss of life among you, only of the ship.
For this very night an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I serve stood beside me
and said, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul; you must stand before Caesar. And look! God has graciously granted you the lives of all who are sailing with you.’
So take heart, men! For I trust God that it will happen exactly as I have been told.
But we must run aground on some island.”
When the fourteenth night came, as we were being driven across the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors suspected they were nearing some land.
They took soundings and found twenty fathoms; after a short distance they took soundings again and found fifteen fathoms.
Fearing that we might run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for daylight to come.
But when the sailors tried to escape from the ship and lowered the boat into the sea under the pretext of laying out anchors from the bow,
Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “Unless these men stay with the ship, you cannot be saved.”
Then the soldiers cut the ropes of the boat and let it fall away.
Just before daybreak, Paul urged them all to take some food, saying, “Today is the fourteenth day you have been in constant suspense, going without food and eating nothing.
Therefore I urge you to take some food, for this is necessary for your survival. For not a hair from the head of any of you will perish.”
After he said this, he took bread, gave thanks to God in the presence of them all, broke it, and began to eat.
Then they all took heart and took food for themselves.
(There were two hundred seventy-six of us in all on the ship.)
When they had eaten as much as they wanted, they lightened the ship by throwing the wheat into the sea.
When day came, they did not recognize the land, but they noticed a bay with a beach, on which they planned to run the ship aground if they could.
So they cast off the anchors and left them in the sea, while at the same time loosening the ropes that held the steering oars. Then, hoisting the foresail to the wind, they headed for the beach.
But striking a place where two seas met, they ran the vessel aground. The bow stuck fast and remained immovable, but the stern began to break up under the violence of the waves.
The soldiers’ plan was to kill the prisoners so that none could swim away and escape.
But the centurion, wanting to save Paul, kept them from their purpose. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and get to land,
and the rest to follow, some on planks and others on pieces of the ship. And in this way, everyone was brought safely to land.

chapters.notes:
**"Consideration" (v. 3)**: The Greek *philanthrōpōs* refers to more than just "kindness"; it denotes a civilized, humane treatment that respects the dignity of the person, often used in a social or political sense.

**"The Fast" (v. 9)**: This refers specifically to *Yom Kippur* (the Day of Atonement). For a first-century audience, this was a chronological marker indicating that it was late September or October, a time when the Mediterranean became treacherous and eventually "closed" to navigation for the winter.

**"Disaster and loss" (v. 10, 21)**: The word *hybris* usually means "insolence" or "pride," but in nautical contexts, it refers to the "violence" or "fury" of the sea. It is paired with *zēmia* (economic or physical loss).

**"Pilot and the ship-owner" (v. 11)**: Greek *kybernētēs* (the helmsman/navigator) and *nauklēros* (the owner or captain of the vessel). These were the technical experts whose advice carried more weight with the Roman centurion than Paul’s prophetic warning.

**"Northeaster" (v. 14)**: The Greek *Eurakylōn* is a hybrid term combining the Greek *Eurus* (east wind) and the Latin *Aquilo* (north wind). It describes a sudden, violent Mediterranean hurricane-force wind.

**"Ship’s boat" (v. 16, 30)**: The *skaphē* was a small dinghy usually towed behind the ship. During a storm, it had to be hoisted on board to prevent it from being smashed or filling with water and dragging the ship down.

**"Undergirding" (v. 17)**: The term *hypozōnnuntes* refers to "frapping"—passing heavy cables or ropes under the hull and tightening them on deck to hold the ship's timbers together under the stress of the waves.

**"Adriatic Sea" (v. 27)**: In the first century, the "Adria" referred to a much larger area of the central Mediterranean between Greece, Italy, and Africa, not just the modern Adriatic Gulf.

**"Fathoms" (v. 28)**: An *orgyia* was the distance between a man's outstretched arms, roughly six feet. This technical maritime term is best rendered by the traditional nautical "fathom."

**"Steering oars" (v. 40)**: Ancient ships did not have a single rudder on a hinge, but two large oars (*pēdalia*) at the stern used for steering. These were lashed up when the ship was at anchor and lowered again for maneuvering.

**"Place where two seas met" (v. 41)**: The term *topon dithalasson* likely describes a sandbar or a channel formed by currents meeting from two different directions, which caused the ship to run aground unexpectedly.

verses.text: Once we had been brought safely through to shore, we then learned that the island was called Malta.
The local people, though they did not speak Greek, showed us extraordinary kindness; they lit a fire and welcomed all of us because of the rain that had set in and the cold.
Paul had gathered a large bundle of dry brushwood and was laying it on the fire when a viper, driven out by the heat, fastened itself onto his hand.
When the locals saw the creature hanging from his hand, they began saying to one another, “Surely this man is a murderer; though he was rescued from the sea, Justice has not allowed him to live.”
He, however, simply shook the creature off into the fire and suffered no ill effects.

They were waiting for him to either swell up with inflammation or suddenly drop dead, but after waiting a long time and seeing nothing out of the ordinary happen to him, they changed their minds and began saying he was a god.
Now in the area around that place, there were lands belonging to the Chief Official of the island, a man named Publius. He welcomed us and hospitably entertained us for three days.
It so happened that Publius’s father was lying in bed, gripped by recurring fevers and dysentery. Paul went in to see him, and after praying and laying his hands on him, he healed him.
After this happened, the rest of the people on the island who had illnesses also came and were cured.
They honored us with many marks of respect, and when we were setting sail, they provided us with everything we needed for our needs.
After three months, we put out to sea in an Alexandrian ship that had wintered at the island; it featured the Twin Brothers as its figurehead.
We put in at Syracuse and stayed there three days,
and from there we tacked around and arrived at Rhegium. A day later, a south wind sprang up, and on the second day we reached Puteoli.
There we found brothers and were invited to stay with them for seven days. And so we came to Rome.
The brothers there, having heard the news about us, came from as far as the Forum of Appius and Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and took courage.
When we entered Rome, Paul was permitted to stay by himself with the soldier who was guarding him.

Three days later, he called together the leaders of the local Jews. When they had assembled, he said to them, “Brothers, though I have done nothing against our people or the customs of our ancestors, I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
After they examined me, they wanted to release me because there was no ground for a death sentence in my case.
But when the Jews objected, I was forced to appeal to Caesar—not that I had any accusation to bring against my own nation.
For this reason, then, I have requested to see you and speak with you, since it is because of the hope of Israel that I am bound with this chain.”
They replied to him, “We have received no letters from Judea concerning you, nor has any of the brothers arrived with an official report or any bad word to say about you.
But we think it right to hear from you what your views are; for regarding this sect, we know that it is spoken against everywhere.”

Having set a day with him, they came to him at his lodging in even greater numbers. From morning until evening, he explained the matter to them, testifying to the kingdom of God and trying to persuade them about Jesus from both the Law of Moses and the Prophets.
Some were persuaded by what was said, but others refused to believe.
Disagreeing among themselves, they began to leave after Paul made one final statement: “The Holy Spirit spoke rightly through Isaiah the prophet to your ancestors
when he said: ‘Go to this people and say: You will listen and listen but never understand, and you will look and look but never perceive.

For the heart of this people has grown calloused; they have become hard of hearing with their ears, and they have shut their eyes—otherwise, they might see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart and turn, and I would heal them.’
Let it be known to you then, that this saving work of God has been sent to the nations; they are the ones who will listen.”
Paul remained for two whole years in his own rented dwelling, and he continued to welcome all who came to him,
proclaiming the kingdom of God and teaching the things concerning the Lord Jesus Christ with all openness, unhindered.

chapters.notes:
**"Local people" / "Locals" (v. 2, 4)**: The Greek *barbaroi* did not carry the modern connotation of "barbaric" or "uncivilized." To a Greek speaker, it simply referred to those who did not speak Greek (onomatopoetically mimicking the "bar-bar" sound of foreign tongues). In this context, it refers to the native Punic-descended inhabitants of Malta who were notably hospitable.

**"Extraordinary kindness" (v. 2)**: The Greek *ou tēn tychousan philanthropian* literally means "not the common/ordinary love-for-humanity." It highlights that the reception was far beyond what shipwrecked strangers might expect.

**"Justice" (v. 4)**: The Greek *hē dikē* likely refers to the personified deity of Justice (Dike). The locals, seeing the viper, interpret it through their theological lens: if the sea didn't kill him, the goddess of Justice is finishing the job.

**"Chief Official" (v. 7)**: The term *tō prōtō tēs nēsou* ("the first [man] of the island") has been confirmed by inscriptions found on Malta as the official Roman title (*primus*) for the governor of the island.

**"Twin Brothers" (v. 11)**: The *Dioskouroi* refers to Castor and Pollux, the sons of Zeus in Greek mythology, who were considered the patrons and protectors of sailors.

**"Sect" (v. 22)**: The Greek *hairesis* (from which we get "heresy") was at this time a neutral term referring to a school of thought, a faction, or a party (used elsewhere in Acts for the Pharisees and Sadducees).

**"Calloused" (v. 27)**: The Greek *epachynthē* (from *pachys*, "thick" or "fat") suggests a heart that has become dull, insensitive, or encased in fat, rendering it unresponsive to spiritual reality. This is a direct quotation from the Septuagint (LXX) of Isaiah 6:9–10.

**"Openness, unhindered" (v. 31)**: The final word of the book in Greek is *akōlytōs* ("unhinderedly"). It is a legal term, but its placement at the very end of Acts is a deliberate literary device by the author to show that despite Paul's physical chains, the message of the Kingdom has reached the heart of the Empire and remains free and unstoppable.
